verses.english: But Elias himself went a day's journey into the wilderness. When he arrived, he sat down under a juniper tree and prayed that he might die, saying: "It is enough, O Lord. Take my life, for I am no better than my ancestors."

verses.latin: Projecitque se et obdormivit in umbra junipetri: et ecce angelus tetigit eum, et dixit illi: Surge, et comede.
verses.english: He then laid down and fell asleep in the shade of the juniper tree. And behold, an angel touched him and said: "Arise, and eat."

verses.latin: Respexit, et ecce ad caput suum panis subcinericius, et vas aquæ: et comedit, et bibit, et rursum dormivit.
verses.english: He looked up and saw, right by his head, a cake baked on hot stones and a jar of water. He ate, drank, and then lay down to sleep again.

verses.latin: Reversusque est angelus Domini secundo, et tetigit eum, dixitque illi: Surge, comede: grandis enim tibi restat via.
verses.english: Then the angel of the Lord returned a second time and touched him, saying: "Arise and eat, for you have a long journey ahead of you."

verses.latin: Qui surrexit, et comedit, et bibit: et ambulavit in fortitudine cibi illius quadraginta diebus et quadraginta noctibus, usque ad montem Dei Horeb.
verses.english: So Elias arose, ate, and drank. And strengthened by that food, he walked for forty days and forty nights until he reached Horeb, the mount of God.

verses.latin: Cumque venisset illuc, mansit in spelunca: et ecce sermo Domini ad eum, et ait illi: Quid agis hic, Elia?
verses.english: When he arrived there, he stayed in a cave. And behold, the word of the Lord came to him, saying: "What are you doing here, Elias?"

verses.latin: Qui respondit: Zelo zelatus sum pro Domino Deo exercituum: quia dereliquerunt pactum tuum filii Israël: aras tuas suffoderunt, et prophetas tuos occiderunt gladio: et derelictus sum ego solus, et quærunt animam meam ut auferant eam.
verses.english: Elias responded: "I am consumed with zeal for the Lord, God of all creation's armies, because the children of Israel have abandoned your covenant. They have torn down your altars and killed your prophets with the sword. I alone am left, and they are seeking to take my life."

verses.latin: Et ait ei: Egredere, et sta in monte coram Domino: et ecce Dominus transit, et spiritus grandis et fortis subvertens montes, et conterens petras ante Dominum: non in spiritu Dominus.
verses.english: Then the Lord said to him: "Go out and stand on the mountain before the Lord." And behold, the Lord was passing by. A great and strong wind tore the mountains apart and broke rocks before the Lord, but the Lord was not in the wind.

verses.latin: Et post spiritum, commotio: et non in commotione Dominus. Et post commotionem, ignis: et non in igne Dominus. Et post ignem, sibilus auræ tenuis.
verses.english: After the wind came an earthquake, but the Lord was not in the earthquake. After the earthquake came fire, but the Lord was not in the fire. And after the fire, there was the whisper of a gentle breeze.

verses.latin: Et cum audisset Elias, operuit vultum suum pallio, et egressus stetit in ostio speluncæ: et ecce vox ad eum dicens: Quid agis hic, Elia?
verses.english: And when Elias heard it, he covered his face with his cloak and went out, standing at the entrance of the cave. And behold, a voice came to him, saying: "What are you doing here, Elias?"

verses.latin: Qui respondit: Zelo zelatus sum pro Domino Deo exercituum: quia dereliquerunt pactum tuum filii Israël: aras tuas suffoderunt, et prophetas tuos occiderunt gladio: et derelictus sum ego solus, et quærunt animam meam ut auferant eam.
verses.english: Elias responded: "I am consumed with zeal for the Lord, God of all creation's armies, because the children of Israel have abandoned your covenant. They have torn down your altars and killed your prophets with the sword. I alone am left, and they are seeking to take my life."

verses.latin: Et ait Dominus ad eum: Vade, et revertare in viam tuam per desertum Damascum: cumque perveneris illuc, unges Hazaël regem Syriæ.
verses.english: Then the Lord said to him: "Go, return on your way through the wilderness to Damascus. When you arrive there, you are to anoint Hazaël as king over Syria."

verses.latin: Et Jehu filium Namsi unges regem Israël: et Eliseum filium Saphat, qui est de Abelmeula, unges prophetam pro te.
verses.english: You shall also anoint Jehu, the son of Namsi, as king over Israel. And Eliseus, the son of Saphat, from Abelmeula, you shall anoint as prophet in your place.

verses.latin: Et erit: quicumque fugerit gladium Hazaël, interficiet eum Jehu: et quicumque fugerit gladium Jehu, interficiet eum Eliseus.
verses.english: And it shall be that whoever escapes the sword of Hazaël, Jehu will put him to death. And whoever escapes the sword of Jehu, Eliseus will put him to death.

verses.latin: Et relinquam mihi in Israël septem millia, omnium genua quæ non sunt curvata Baal, et omne os quod non adoravit eum.
verses.english: Yet I will preserve for myself seven thousand in Israel: all the knees that have not bowed to Baal, and every mouth that has not worshipped him.

verses.latin: Profectus itaque Elias de loco illo, invenit Eliseum filium Saphat, arantem in duodecim jugis boum: et ipse in duodecim jugis arabat: cumque venisset Elias ad eum, misit pallium suum super illum.
verses.english: So Elias departed from that place and found Eliseus, the son of Saphat, plowing with twelve pairs of oxen. He himself was with the twelfth pair. And when Elias came to him, he threw his cloak over him — a symbolic gesture of calling and succession.

verses.latin: At ille statim relictis bobus, cucurrit post Eliam, et ait: Osculer, obsecro, patrem meum et matrem meam, et sic sequar te. Cui ille ait: Vade, et revertere: quod enim meum erat, feci tibi.
verses.english: Immediately, Eliseus left the oxen and ran after Elias. He said: "Please let me kiss my father and my mother, and then I will follow you." Elias replied: "Go, and return. For what was my part, I have done to you."

verses.latin: Reversus autem ab eo, tulit jugum boum, et immolavit illud, et in aratro boum coxit carnes, et dedit populo, et comederunt: et surgens abiit, et secutus est Eliam, et ministravit ei.
verses.english: So Eliseus returned from Elias, took a pair of oxen, and sacrificed them. He cooked their meat using the wooden parts of the plows as fuel, and gave it to the people, and they ate. Then he arose, went after Elias, and served him.

verses.latin: Et nuntiavit Achab Jezabel omnia quae fecerat Elias, et quomodo occidisset universos prophetas gladio.
verses.english: And Ahab told Jezebel everything Elijah had done, and how Elijah had executed all the false prophets with a sword.

verses.latin: Misit itaque Jezabel nuntium ad Eliam, dicens: Haec faciant mihi dii, et haec addant, nisi hac hora cras animam tuam fecero sicut unius ex illis.
verses.english: So Jezebel sent a messenger to Elijah with a message: 'May my gods do to me and more also if, by this time tomorrow, I do not make your life like the life of one of those prophets he killed.'

verses.latin: Timuit ergo Elias, et surgens abiit quocumque eum ferre poterat voluntas: et venit in Bersabee Juda, et dimisit ibi puerum suum.
verses.english: Elijah was afraid, so he got up and went wherever he felt led to flee. He came to Beersheba in Judah and left his servant there.

verses.latin: Et ipse perrexit in desertum, via unius diei: cumque venisset, et sederet subter unam juniperum, petivit animae suae ut moreretur, et dixit: Sufficit mihi, Domine: tolle animam meam: non enim melior sum quam patres mei.
verses.english: Then he himself traveled into the desert, a day's journey. When he arrived, he sat down under a single juniper tree. He prayed for himself to die and said, 'I have had enough, Lord. Take my life, for I am no better than my ancestors.'

verses.latin: Et projecit se, et obdormivit in umbra juniperae: et ecce angelus tetigit eum, et dixit illi: Surge, et comede.
verses.english: He lay down and fell asleep in the shade of the juniper tree. Suddenly, an angel touched him and said to him, 'Get up and eat!'

verses.latin: Respexit, et ecce ad caput suum subcinericius panis, et vas aquae: et comedit, et bibit, et rursum obdormivit.
verses.english: He looked, and there by his head was a freshly baked loaf of bread and a jar of water. So he ate and drank, and then lay down and fell asleep again.

verses.latin: Reversusque est angelus Domini secundo, et tetigit eum, dixitque illi: Surge, comede: grandis enim tibi restat via.
verses.english: And the angel of the Lord returned a second time and touched him and said to him, 'Get up and eat, for you have a long journey ahead of you.'

verses.latin: Qui consurgens comedit, et bibit, et ambulavit in fortitudine cibi illius quadraginta diebus, et quadraginta noctibus, usque ad montem Dei Horeb.
verses.english: So he got up, ate, and drank. And he walked for forty days and forty nights, sustained by the strength of that food, until he reached Horeb, the mountain of God.

verses.latin: Cumque illuc venisset, mansit in spelunca: et ecce sermo Domini ad eum, et dixit illi: Quid hic agis, Elia?
verses.english: When he arrived there, he stayed in a cave. And behold, the word of the Lord came to him and said to him, 'What are you doing here, Elijah?'

verses.latin: Qui respondit: Zelo zelatus sum pro Domino Deo exercituum: quia dereliquerunt pactum tuum filii Israel: aras tuas destruxerunt, et prophetas tuos occiderunt gladio: et derelictus sum ego solus, et quaerunt animam meam ut auferant eam.
verses.english: He answered, 'I have been very zealous for the Lord, the God of Hosts, because the children of Israel have abandoned Your covenant. They have torn down Your altars, and they have executed Your prophets with a sword. And I am left all alone, and they are seeking to take my life away.'

verses.latin: Et dixit ei: Egredere, et sta in monte coram Domino: et ecce Dominus transit, et spiritus grandis et fortis subvertens montes, et conterens petras ante Dominum: non in spiritu Dominus.
verses.english: And He said to him, 'Go out and stand on the mountain before the Lord.' And behold, the Lord is about to pass by. And a great and powerful wind began to tear apart the mountains and shatter rocks before the Lord, but the Lord was not in the wind.

verses.latin: Et post spiritum commotio: non in commotione Dominus. Et post commotionem ignis: non in igne Dominus. Et post ignem sibilus aurae tenuis.
verses.english: After the wind, there was an earthquake, but the Lord was not in the earthquake. After the earthquake, there was a fire, but the Lord was not in the fire. And after the fire, there was the soft sound of a gentle breeze.

verses.latin: Et cum audisset Elias, operuit vultum suum pallio, et egressus stetit in ostio speluncae: et ecce vox ad eum dicens: Quid hic agis, Elia?
verses.english: And when Elijah heard it, he covered his face with his cloak, and went out and stood at the entrance of the cave. And behold, a voice came to him saying, 'What are you doing here, Elijah?'

verses.latin: Qui respondit: Zelo zelatus sum pro Domino Deo exercituum: quia dereliquerunt pactum tuum filii Israel: aras tuas destruxerunt, et prophetas tuos occiderunt gladio: et derelictus sum ego solus, et quaerunt animam meam ut auferant eam.
verses.english: He answered, 'I have been very zealous for the Lord, the God of Hosts, because the children of Israel have abandoned Your covenant. They have torn down Your altars, and they have executed Your prophets with a sword. And I am left all alone, and they are seeking to take my life away.'

verses.latin: Et dixit Dominus ad eum: Vade, et revertare in viam tuam per desertum in Damascum: cumque perveneris illuc, unges Hazaël regem Syriae.
verses.english: And the Lord said to him, 'Go, and return by your path through the desert toward Damascus. And when you arrive there, you are to anoint Hazael as king over Syria.'

verses.latin: Et Jehu filium Namsi unges regem Israel: et Eliseum filium Saphat, qui est de Abelmeula, unges prophetam pro te.
verses.english: You are also to anoint Jehu, the son of Nimshi, as king over Israel. And Elisha, the son of Shaphat, who is from Abel-meholah, you are to anoint as prophet in your place.

verses.latin: Et erit: quicumque fugerit gladium Hazaël, occidet eum Jehu: et quicumque fugerit gladium Jehu, occidet eum Eliseus.
verses.english: And it shall come to pass that whoever escapes Hazael's sword, Jehu will kill them. And whoever escapes Jehu's sword, Elisha will kill them.

verses.latin: Et relinquam mihi in Israel septem millia, omnium genua quae non sunt curvata ante Baal, et omne os quod non adoravit eum.
verses.english: And I will preserve for Myself in Israel seven thousand people, all whose knees have not bowed down before Baal, and every mouth that has not worshiped him.

verses.latin: Et profectus inde Elias, invenit Eliseum filium Saphat, arantem in duodecim jugis boum: et ipse in duodecimo arabat. Cumque venisset Elias ad eum, misit pallium suum super illum.
verses.english: So Elijah departed from there and found Elisha, the son of Shaphat, plowing with twelve teams of oxen; he himself was guiding the twelfth team. When Elijah came to him, he threw his cloak over him.

verses.latin: Et statim ille derelictis bubus cucurrit post Eliam, et ait: Osculer, oro, patrem meum et matrem meam, et sic sequar te. Et ille dixit ei: Vade, et revertere: quid enim feci tibi?
verses.english: Immediately, he left the oxen and ran after Elijah and said, 'Please allow me to go kiss my father and mother goodbye, and then I will follow you.' And Elijah said to him, 'Go and return! For what have I done to hinder you?'

verses.latin: Reversus autem ab eo, tulit jugum boum, et immolavit illos, et in aratro boum coxit carnes, et dedit populo, et comederunt: et surgens abiit, et secutus est Eliam, et ministravit ei.
verses.english: So Elisha returned from him. He took a yoke of oxen and slaughtered them as a sacrifice, and with the plowing equipment, he cooked the meat and gave it to the people, and they ate. Then he got up, went, followed Elijah, and served him.

verses.latin: Et nuntiavit Achab Jezabel omnia quae fecerat Elias, et quomodo occidisset universos prophetas gladio.
verses.english: And Ahab informed Jezebel about everything Elijah had done, including how he had killed all the false prophets of Baal with a sword.

verses.latin: Misit igitur Jezabel nuntium ad Eliam, dicens: Haec faciant mihi dii, et haec addant, nisi hac hora cras animam tuam fecero sicut animam unius ex illis.
verses.english: So Jezebel sent a messenger to Elijah, saying: 'May *my* pagan gods do this to me, and even more severe punishment add to it, if by this time tomorrow I do not make your life like the life of one of those false prophets Elijah killed!'

verses.latin: Timuit ergo Elias, et surgens abiit quocumque eum ferebat animus: venitque Bersabee Juda, et dimisit ibi puerum suum.
verses.english: So Elijah was afraid, and rising, he left and went wherever his spirit carried him. He came to Beer-sheba in Judah, and he left his servant boy there.

verses.latin: Et ipse perrexit in desertum via unius diei: cumque venisset, et sederet subter unam juniperum, petivit animae suae ut moreretur, et dixit: Sufficit mihi, Domine, tolle animam meam: neque enim melior sum quam patres mei.
verses.english: And he himself went a day's journey into the wilderness. When he arrived, and sat under a broom tree, he asked for his life to end, and he said: 'It is enough for me now, O Lord; take away my life, for I am no better than my ancestors!'

verses.latin: Et projecit se, et obdormivit in umbra juniperi: et ecce angelus Domini tetigit eum, et dixit illi: Surge, et comede.
verses.english: And he lay down and fell asleep in the shade of the broom tree. And behold, an angel of the Lord touched him and said to him: 'Rise and eat.'

verses.latin: Respexit, et ecce ad caput suum subcinericius panis, et vas aquae: et comedit, et bibit, et rursum obdormivit.
verses.english: He looked, and behold, at his head was a hearth-cake—bread baked on hot stones—and a jar of water. And he ate and drank, and lay down to sleep again.

verses.latin: Reversusque est angelus Domini secundo, et tetigit eum, dixitque illi: Surge, comede: grandis enim tibi restat via.
verses.english: And the angel of the Lord returned a second time and touched him, and said to him: 'Rise and eat, for a long journey still awaits you.'

verses.latin: Qui surrexit, et comedit, et bibit, et ambulavit in fortitudine cibi illius quadraginta diebus, et quadraginta noctibus, usque ad montem Dei Horeb.
verses.english: So he rose, and ate and drank, and he walked in the strength of that food for forty days and forty nights, all the way to Horeb, the mountain of God.

verses.latin: Cumque illuc pervenisset, mansit in spelunca: et ecce sermo Domini ad eum, et ait illi: Quid agis hic, Elia?
verses.english: When he arrived there, he stayed in a cave. And behold, the word of the Lord came to him, and said to him: 'What are you doing here, Elijah?'

verses.latin: Qui respondit: Zelo zelatus sum pro Domino Deo exercituum: quia dereliquerunt pactum tuum filii Israel: altaria tua destruxerunt, et prophetas tuos occiderunt gladio: et ego relictus sum solus, et quaerunt animam meam ut auferant eam.
verses.english: He responded: 'I have been very zealous for the Lord, the God of armies and heavenly hosts, because the children of Israel have abandoned your covenant. They have destroyed your altars, and they have killed your prophets with the sword. And I alone am left, and they seek to take my life away.'

verses.latin: Et ait ei: Egredere, et sta in monte coram Domino: et ecce Dominus transit, et spiritus grandis, et fortis subvertens montes, et conterens petras ante Dominum: non in spiritu Dominus.
verses.english: And He said to him: 'Go out and stand on the mountain before the Lord.' And behold, the Lord passed by, and a great and strong wind tore down the mountains and shattered rocks before the Lord. But the Lord was not in that violent wind.

verses.latin: Et post spiritum commotio: et non in commotione Dominus. Et post commotionem ignis: et non in igne Dominus. Et post ignem sibilus aurae tenuis.
verses.english: And after the wind, there was an earthquake, but the Lord was not in the earthquake. And after the earthquake, there was a fire, but the Lord was not in the fire. And after the fire, there was the sound of a gentle, soft whisper.

verses.latin: Quod cum audisset Elias, operuit vultum suum pallio, et egressus stetit in ostio speluncae: et ecce vox ad eum dicens: Quid agis hic, Elia?
verses.english: When Elijah heard it, he covered his face with his mantle, and went out and stood at the entrance of the cave. And behold, a voice came to him, saying: 'What are you doing here, Elijah?'

verses.latin: Qui respondit: Zelo zelatus sum pro Domino Deo exercituum: quia dereliquerunt pactum tuum filii Israel: altaria tua destruxerunt, et prophetas tuos occiderunt gladio: et ego relictus sum solus, et quaerunt animam meam ut auferant eam.
verses.english: He responded: 'I have been very zealous for the Lord, the God of armies and heavenly hosts, because the children of Israel have abandoned your covenant. They have destroyed your altars, and they have killed your prophets with the sword. And I alone am left, and they seek to take my life away.'

verses.latin: Et ait Dominus ad eum: Vade, et revertare in viam tuam per desertum in Damascum: cumque perveneris illuc, unges Hazaël regem Syriae.
verses.english: And the Lord said to him: 'Go, and return on your way through the wilderness to Damascus. And when you arrive there, you shall anoint Hazael as king over Aram (Syria).'

verses.latin: Et Jehu filium Namsi unges regem super Israel: Eliseum autem filium Saphat, qui est de Abelmeula, unges prophetam pro te.
verses.english: And you shall anoint Jehu, the son of Nimshi, as king over Israel. And Elisha, the son of Shaphat, who is from Abel-meholah, you shall anoint as a prophet in your place.

verses.latin: Et erit: quicumque fugerit gladium Hazaël, interficiet eum Jehu: et quicumque fugerit gladium Jehu, interficiet eum Eliseus.
verses.english: And it shall come to pass: whoever escapes the sword of Hazael, Jehu shall kill him. And whoever escapes the sword of Jehu, Elisha shall effectively cause his death through divine judgment.

verses.latin: Et relinquam mihi in Israel septem millia, omnium genua quae non sunt curvata ante Baal, et omne os quod non adoravit eum.
verses.english: Yet I will leave for myself in Israel seven thousand people, all whose knees have not bowed before Baal, and every mouth that has not worshipped him.

verses.latin: Et profectus inde Elias, invenit Eliseum filium Saphat arantem in duodecim jugeribus boum: et ipse in duodecim jugis arabat: cumque venisset Elias ad eum, misit pallium suum super illum.
verses.english: So Elijah departed from there and found Elisha, the son of Shaphat, plowing with twelve yokes of oxen, and Elisha himself was with the twelfth yoke. And when Elijah came to him, he threw his mantle over him, signifying the passing of prophetic authority.

verses.latin: Qui statim relictis bobus, cucurrit post Eliam, et ait: Osculer oro patrem meum, et matrem meam, et sic sequar te. Et ille dixit illi: Vade, et revertere: quid enim feci tibi?
verses.english: Elisha immediately left the oxen, ran after Elijah, and said: 'Please let me kiss my father and my mother goodbye, and then I will follow you.' And Elijah said to him: 'Go back to your family, and then return; for what have I done to you? (My action was a clear call to prophetic duty, not something to be lightly taken).'

verses.latin: Reversusque ab eo, tulit jugum boum, et mactavit, et coxit carnes eorum in aratro boum, et dedit populo, et comederunt: et surgens abiit, et secutus est Eliam, et ministravit ei.
verses.english: So he returned from Elijah, took a yoke of oxen, and sacrificed them. And he cooked their meat using the plowing equipment as fuel, and gave it to the people, and they ate. Then he arose, went, and followed Elijah, and served him as his attendant.

verses.latin: Benadad rex Syriae congregavit omnem exercitum suum et triginta duos reges secum et equos et currus et ascendit et pugnabat contra Samariam et obsidebat eam.
verses.english: Ben-hadad, the king of Syria, gathered his entire army, and thirty-two other kings were with him. He had many horses and chariots. He marched and fought against the city-state of Samaria and began to besiege it.

verses.latin: Misitque nuntios ad Achab regem Israël in civitatem
verses.english: Then he sent messengers to King Ahab of Israel, into the city of Samaria.

verses.latin: et ait Hæc dicit Benadad Argentum tuum et aurum tuum meum est et uxores tuæ et filii tui optimi mei sunt.
verses.english: Ben-hadad's message said: 'This is what Ben-hadad says: Your silver and your gold are mine. And your finest wives and your children are mine as well.'

verses.latin: Responditque rex Israël juxta verbum tuum rex meus sum ego et omnia quæ mea sunt.
verses.english: The king of Israel responded, 'As you have said, my lord king, I am yours, and everything I possess belongs to you.'

verses.latin: Revertentesque nuntii dixerunt Hæc dicit Benadad Misi ad te dicens argentum tuum et aurum tuum et uxores tuas et filios tuos dabis mihi
verses.english: The messengers returned and said, 'This is what Ben-hadad says: I sent word to you, saying, "You shall hand over your silver and your gold, your wives and your children to me."

verses.latin: cras ergo hora hac mittam servos meos ad te et scrutabuntur domos tuas et domos servorum tuorum et omne quod eis placuerit in manu sua auferent.
verses.english: Therefore, tomorrow at this time, I will send my servants to you. They will search your house and the houses of your servants, and they will seize and take away with their own hands whatever pleases them.'

verses.latin: Et convocavit Achab omnes seniores terræ et ait Animadvertite et videte quoniam insidias facit vobiscum misit enim ad me pro uxoribus meis et pro filiis meis et pro argento et auro et non abnegavi.
verses.english: So Ahab called together all the elders of the land and said, 'Notice this, and see that he is seeking trouble with us. He sent to me for my wives and my children, and for my silver and gold, and I did not refuse him.'

verses.latin: Dixeruntque illi omnes majores natu et universus populus Ne acquiescas neque audias.
verses.english: Then all the elders and all the people said to him, 'Do not consent, and do not listen to his demands.'

verses.latin: Itaque respondit nuntiis Benadad Dicite domino meo regi Hæc dicit Achab omne quod primum misisti ad me servus tuus faciet hoc autem facere non possum. Reversique nuntii retulerunt ei.
verses.english: So Ahab responded to Ben-hadad's messengers, saying, 'Tell my lord the king: All that you first sent to me, your servant will do. But this second demand, I cannot do.' The messengers returned and reported this to Ben-hadad.

verses.latin: Misit ergo ad eum Benadad dicens Hæc faciant mihi dii et hæc addant si suffecerit pulvis Samariæ pugillis omnium populorum qui sequuntur me.
verses.english: Then Ben-hadad sent a message to Ahab, saying, 'May the pagan gods do this to me, and more also, if the dust of Samaria is enough to fill the hands of all the people who are following me to battle!'

verses.latin: Et respondens rex Israël ait Dicite ei ne glorietur accinctus æque ut discinctus.
verses.english: The king of Israel responded, saying, 'Tell him: Let not him who puts on his armor boast as much as he who takes it off after victory.'

verses.latin: Factum est autem cum audisset verbum hoc Benadad bibens ipse et reges in papilionibus et ait servis suis Ponite. Et posuerunt exercitum contra civitatem.
verses.english: Now it happened that when Ben-hadad heard this word, he was drinking with the other kings in their tents. He said to his servants, 'Prepare for attack!' And they positioned the army against the city.

verses.latin: Et ecce propheta accedens ad Achab regem Israël ait Hæc dicit Dominus Num vidisti omnem multitudinem hanc Ecce ego tradam illam in manu tua hodie et scies quoniam ego Dominus.
verses.english: Then, behold, a prophet approached King Ahab of Israel and said, 'This is what the Lord says: Have you seen all this great multitude? Behold, I will deliver them into your hand today, and you shall know that I am the Lord, the one true God.'

verses.latin: Et ait Achab Per quem Dixit ei Dominus Per pedisequos principum provinciarum. Et ait Quis incipiet prælium Cui ille respondit Tu.
verses.english: Ahab asked, 'By whom will you do this?' The Lord replied to him, 'By the young men who are the servants of the provincial governors.' And Ahab asked, 'Who will begin the battle?' The prophet answered him, 'You will.'

verses.latin: Recensuit ergo Achab pueros principum provinciarum et repperit numerum ducentorum triginta duorum et post eos recensuit omne vulgus filiorum Israël septem milium.
verses.english: So Ahab mustered the young men of the provincial governors and found their number to be two hundred and thirty-two. After them, he mustered all the common people of the sons of Israel, seven thousand in total.

verses.latin: Et egressi sunt meridie Benadad autem bibebat temulentus in papilionibus ipse et reges triginta duo qui ad eum vocabantur.
verses.english: They marched out at noon. Ben-hadad, meanwhile, was drunk in his tents, along with the thirty-two kings who had been summoned to him.

verses.latin: Egressique sunt pueri principum provinciarum primi. Misit ergo Benadad Qui nuntiaverunt ei dicentes Viri egressi sunt de Samaria.
verses.english: The young men of the provincial governors went out first. Ben-hadad sent out scouts who reported to him, 'Men have come out from Samaria!'

verses.latin: At ille ait Sive pro pace veniunt adprehendite eos vivos sive ut pugnent vivos conprehendite.
verses.english: Ben-hadad then said, 'Whether they have come out for peace, seize them alive; or if they have come out to fight, seize them alive.'

verses.latin: Egressi sunt ergo pueri principum provinciarum et exercitus post eos.
verses.english: So the young men of the provincial governors went out, and the rest of the army followed behind them.

verses.latin: Et percussit unusquisque virum qui contra se venerat fugeruntque Syri et persecutus est eos Israël Fugit quoque Benadad rex Syriæ in equo cum equitibus suis.
verses.english: Each man struck down the opponent who came against him. The Syrians fled, and Israel pursued them. Ben-hadad, the king of Syria, also fled on his horse with his horsemen.

verses.latin: Egressus itaque rex Israël percussit equos et currus et percussit Syriam plaga magna.
verses.english: So the king of Israel went out and struck down the horses and chariots, and he inflicted a great defeat on Syria.

verses.latin: Accedens autem propheta ad regem Israël ait ei Vade et confortare et scito et vide quid facias revertente enim anno rex Syriæ ascendet contra te.
verses.english: Then the prophet approached the king of Israel and said to him, 'Go, strengthen yourself, and take note and see what you must do. For when the year comes around again, the king of Syria will march up against you.'

verses.latin: Porro servi regis Syriæ dixerunt ei Dii montium sunt dii eorum ideo superaverunt nos at si pugnaverimus contra illos in campestribus superabimus eos.
verses.english: Now the servants of the king of Syria said to him, 'Their gods are gods of the mountains; that is why they overpowered us. But if we fight against them on the plains, we will surely overpower them.'

verses.latin: Tu ergo verbum hoc fac remoue omnes reges de exercitu tuo et pone principes pro eis
verses.english: Therefore, do this: remove all the other kings from your army, and put military commanders in their places.

verses.latin: et instaura numerum militum juxta præcedentem exercitum et equos ut prius et currus ut antea et pugnabimus contra eos in campestribus et videbimus si non superabimus eos. Credidit ergo consilio eorum et fecit ita.
verses.english: Then rebuild the number of soldiers, according to the previous army, and the horses as before, and the chariots as before. Then we will fight them on the plains, and we will see if we do not overpower them.' Ben-hadad believed their counsel and acted accordingly.

verses.latin: Itaque post annos septem recensuit Benadad Syros et ascendit Afec ut pugnaret contra Israël.
verses.english: And so, after seven years, Ben-hadad mustered the Syrians and marched to Aphek to fight against Israel.

verses.latin: Porro filii Israël recensiti sunt et sumptis cibariis profecti ex adverso eorum quasi duo parvi greges caprarum Syri autem repleverunt terram.
verses.english: But the sons of Israel were also mustered and, having taken provisions, went out to confront them. They appeared like two small flocks of goats, while the Syrians, in contrast, filled the entire land.

verses.latin: Et accedens vir Dei dixit ad regem Israël Hæc dicit Dominus Quia dixerunt Syri Deus montium est Dominus et non est Deus vallium dabo omnem multitudinem hanc in manu tua et scietis quia ego Dominus.
verses.english: Then a man of God approached the king of Israel and said, 'This is what the Lord says: Because the Syrians declared, 'The Lord is a god of the mountains, and not a god of the valleys,' I will give all this great multitude into your hand, and you shall know that I am the Lord, the one true God.'

verses.latin: Et exercuerunt se ex adverso alterutrum septem diebus septimo autem die inito certamine percusserunt filii Israël de Syris centum milia peditum in una die.
verses.english: They camped opposite each other for seven days. On the seventh day, the battle began. The sons of Israel struck down one hundred thousand Syrian foot soldiers in a single day.

verses.latin: Et fugerunt qui reliqui fuerant in civitatem Afec et cecidit murus super viginti septem milia virorum qui reliqui fuerant Benadad autem fugiens ingressus est civitatem in cubiculum de cubiculo.
verses.english: The remaining soldiers fled into the city of Aphek, and the city wall collapsed upon twenty-seven thousand of the men who were left. Ben-hadad himself fled and entered the city, hiding in an inner chamber.

verses.latin: Dixeruntque ei servi sui Ecce audivimus reges domus Israël clementes esse mittamus ergo saccos in lumbos nostros et funes in caput nostrum et egrediamur ad regem Israël forsitan salvabit animas nostras.
verses.english: His servants said to him, 'Behold, we have heard that the kings of the house of Israel are merciful. Let us therefore put sackcloth on our bodies and ropes around our heads, and go out to the king of Israel. Perhaps he will save our lives.'

verses.latin: Accinxerunt itaque saccis lumbos suos et posuerunt funes in capitibus suis et venerunt ad regem Israël et dixerunt Servus tuus Benadad dicit Vivat oro te anima mea. At ille ait Si adhuc vivit frater meus est.
verses.english: So they put sackcloth on their bodies and ropes around their heads. They came to the king of Israel and said, 'Your servant Ben-hadad says, 'Please let my life be spared!'' Ahab replied, 'If he is still alive, he is my brother.'

verses.latin: Quod acceperunt viri pro omine et festinantes rapuerunt de ore ejus atque dixerunt Frater tuus Benadad. Et ille ait Ite et adducite eum. Egressus est ergo Benadad ad eum et ascendit currum suum.
verses.english: The men took this as a good omen, quickly seizing upon his words, and said, 'Your brother Ben-hadad!' Ahab then said, 'Go and bring him here.' So Ben-hadad came out to him, and Ahab had him come up into his chariot.

verses.latin: Dixitque ei Benadad Civitates quas abstulit pater meus a patre tuo reddam et plateas facias tibi in Damasco sicut fecit pater meus in Samaria. Et ego in fœdere dimittam te. Pepigit ergo Achab fœdus cum eo et dimisit eum.
verses.english: Ben-hadad said to him, 'The cities that my father took from your father, I will restore. And you may establish trading quarters for yourself in Damascus, just as my father established them in Samaria.' Ahab said, 'I will make a covenant with you and then release you.' So Ahab made a covenant with him and released him.

verses.latin: Tunc vir quidam de filiis prophetarum dixit in verbo Domini ad socium suum Percute me. Qui noluit percutere.
verses.english: Then one of the sons of the prophets, according to a command from the Lord, said to his companion, 'Strike me!' But his companion refused to strike him.

verses.latin: Et ille ait Quia noluisti audire vocem Domini ecce auferet te leo et percussit eum leo et interfecit.
verses.english: The prophet then said, 'Because you refused to obey the voice of the Lord, behold, a lion will kill you!' And indeed, a lion found him and killed him.

verses.latin: Et abiit ad virum alterum et ait Percute me. Qui percussit eum et vulneravit.
verses.english: Then he went to another man and said, 'Strike me!' And the man struck him and wounded him.

verses.latin: Abiit ergo propheta et expectavit regem in via et simulavit se esse vulneratum opertis oculis suis pulvere.
verses.english: So the prophet went and waited for the king by the road, disguising himself as if wounded, with his eyes covered by dust.

verses.latin: Cumque transiret rex clamavit ad regem et ait Servus tuus egressus est ad pugnandum cominus cum quidam recessisset adduxit virum ad me et ait Custodi virum istum et si lapsus fuerit aliquid de eo erit anima tua pro anima ejus aut pendes talentum argenti.
verses.english: As the king passed by, the prophet cried out to him and said, 'Your servant went out into the midst of the battle. And behold, when a man had turned aside, he brought a man to me and said, 'Guard this man. If he escapes in any way, your life will be taken for his life, or you will pay a talent of silver.''

verses.latin: Cumque ego turbatus huc illucque discurrerem subito non conparuit. Et ait rex Israël ad eum Hoc est judicium tuum quod ipse decrevisti.
verses.english: 'While your servant was distracted and busy here and there, the man suddenly disappeared.' The king of Israel said to him, 'That is your judgment, for you have decreed it yourself.'

verses.latin: Benadad ergo rex Syriae congregavit omnem exercitum suum: et triginta duo reges cum eo, et equos et currus: et ascendens abiit, et obsidebat Samariam, et pugnabat adversum eam.
verses.english: Ben-Hadad, the king of Syria, gathered his entire army, which included thirty-two kings with their horses and chariots. He then marched up to Samaria and besieged it, preparing to fight against the city.

verses.latin: Mittensque nuntios ad Achab regem Israel in civitatem,
verses.english: He sent messengers to King Ahab of Israel, who was inside the city.

verses.latin: ait: Hæc dicit Benadad: Argentum tuum, et aurum tuum, et uxores tuas, et filios tuos optimos, mei sunt.
verses.english: The message from Ben-Hadad said: 'Your silver and gold, your wives, and the best of your children are all mine.'

verses.latin: Responditque rex Israel: Juxta verbum tuum, rex meus, mei sumus, et omnia quæ nostra sunt.
verses.english: The king of Israel replied: 'As you say, my lord king, I am yours, and all that I possess is yours.'

verses.latin: Revertentesque nuntii dixerunt illi: Hæc dicit Benadad: Misi ad te, dicens: Argentum tuum, et aurum tuum, et uxores tuas, et filios tuos dabis mihi.
verses.english: The messengers returned to Ben-Hadad and delivered his response. But Ben-Hadad sent them back with a new message: 'I sent to you earlier, stating that you must give me your silver, your gold, your wives, and your children.'

verses.latin: Crastina igitur hac hora mittam servos meos ad te, et scrutabuntur domos tuas, et thesauros servorum tuorum: et omne quod eis placuerit, auferent.
verses.english: 'Therefore, by this time tomorrow, I will send my servants to you. They will search through your house and the houses of your officials, and they will take away whatever they desire.'

verses.latin: Et convocavit rex Israel omnes senes terræ, et ait: Animadvertite, et videte quod insidietur nobis: misit enim ad me de uxoribus meis, et de filiis meis, et de argento et auro, et non abnui.
verses.english: King Ahab called together all the elders of the land and said: 'Notice how this man is seeking to destroy us. He first sent for my wives and children, and my silver and gold, and I did not refuse him.'

verses.latin: Dixeruntque omnes majores natu, et universus populus ei: Non acquiescas, neque audias.
verses.english: All the elders and all the people told him: 'Do not agree to this, nor listen to his demands.'

verses.latin: Respondit ergo nuntiis Benadad: Dicite regi meo: Omne quod misisti ad me primum, faciam: hoc autem non possum facere.
verses.english: So Ahab responded to Ben-Hadad’s messengers: 'Tell my lord the king: Everything you first demanded, I will do. But this latest demand I cannot fulfill.'

verses.latin: Reversique nuntii retulerunt ei. Ille quoque misit ad eum, dicens: Hæc faciant mihi dii, et hæc addant, si suffecerit pulvis Samariæ pugillis omnium populorum qui sequuntur me.
verses.english: The messengers returned and reported this to Ben-Hadad. Ben-Hadad then sent a message to Ahab, saying: 'May the gods punish me severely and even more if the dust of Samaria is enough to fill the handfuls of all the people who follow me!' —meaning, 'My army is so vast, Samaria will be utterly destroyed and turn to dust, and there won't even be enough dust to fill their hands.'

verses.latin: Et respondens rex Israel, ait: Dicite: Ne glorietur accinctus æque ut discinctus.
verses.english: The king of Israel responded to Ben-Hadad: 'Tell him this: One who is putting on his armor for battle should not boast as if he were taking it off after victory.'

verses.latin: Porro Benadad bibebat, et reliqui reges in tabernaculis: et audita est vox ista. Et ait servis suis: Circumdate civitatem. Et circumdederunt eam.
verses.english: Meanwhile, Ben-Hadad and the other kings were drinking in their temporary shelters when this message was delivered. Ben-Hadad then said to his servants: 'Surround the city for attack!' So they surrounded Samaria.

verses.latin: Ecce autem propheta accedit ad Achab regem Israel, dicens: Hæc dicit Dominus: Cerne omnem multitudinem hanc nimiam, ecce ego tradam eam in manu tua hodie: et scies quia ego Dominus.
verses.english: Then a prophet approached King Ahab of Israel, saying: 'The Lord says this: 'See this immense multitude? Indeed, I will deliver them into your hand today, so you will know that I am the Lord.''

verses.latin: Et ait Achab: Per quem? At ille respondit: Hæc dicit Dominus: Per famulos principum provinciarum. Et ait Achab: Quis incipiet mittere aciem? Et ille ait: Tu.
verses.english: Ahab asked: 'By whose hand will this be done?' The prophet replied: 'The Lord says this: 'Through the young men who serve the provincial governors.'' Ahab then asked: 'Who will begin the battle?' And the prophet said: 'You will.'

verses.latin: Recensuit ergo Achab famulos principum provinciarum, et invenit numerum ducentorum triginta duorum: et post eos recensuit populum, omnes filios Israel, septem millia.
verses.english: So Ahab counted the young men who served the provincial governors, and found two hundred and thirty-two of them. After them, he counted all the people, all the sons of Israel, totaling seven thousand.

verses.latin: Et egressi sunt meridie. Benadad autem bibebat temulentus in tabernaculis, et reges triginta duo cum eo, qui ad auxilium ejus venerant.
verses.english: They marched out at noon. Ben-Hadad, however, was in his temporary shelter, drinking heavily with the thirty-two kings who had come to aid him.

verses.latin: Egressique sunt famuli principum provinciarum primi. Misissetque Benadad: qui nuntiaverunt ei, dicentes: Viri egressi sunt de Samaria.
verses.english: The young men serving the provincial governors were the first to march out. Ben-Hadad had sent scouts, who reported to him: 'Men are coming out from Samaria.'

verses.latin: At ille ait: Sive pro pace veniunt, apprehendite eos vivos: sive ut pugnent, vivos capite.
verses.english: Ben-Hadad said: 'If they come out for peace, take them alive. If they come out to fight, capture them alive.'

verses.latin: Egressi sunt ergo de civitate, pueri principum provinciarum, et exercitus post eos.
verses.english: So the young men from the provincial governors' retinues marched out of the city, with the main Israelite army following behind them.

verses.latin: Et percussit unusquisque virum suum: fugeruntque Syri, et persecutus est eos Israel. Fugit quoque Benadad rex Syriae in equo, et cum equitibus suis.
verses.english: Each Israelite soldier struck down his opponent. The Syrians fled in disarray, and Israel pursued them. Ben-Hadad, the king of Syria, also fled on horseback with his cavalry.

verses.latin: Egressus itaque rex Israel percussit equos et currus, et interfecit Syriam plaga magna.
verses.english: The king of Israel then rode out and struck down the Syrian horses and chariots, inflicting a great slaughter upon Syria.

verses.latin: Accessit autem propheta ad regem Israel, dicens ei: Vade, et confortare, et scito, et vide quid agas: quoniam annuente temporis revertetur rex Syriae contra te.
verses.english: The prophet again approached the king of Israel and said to him: 'Go and strengthen yourself. Take note and consider carefully what you must do, because at the turn of the year, the king of Syria will return to fight against you.'

verses.latin: Servi vero regis Syriae dixerunt ei: Dii montium sunt dii eorum, ideo superaverunt nos: sed melius est ut pugnemus contra eos in campestribus, et superabimus eos.
verses.english: The servants of the king of Syria said to him: 'Their gods are gods of the mountains; that is why they overpowered us. But it is better that we fight against them on the plains, and then we will surely defeat them.'

verses.latin: Tu ergo hoc verbum fac: amove reges, unumquemque de statu suo: et pone principes pro eis:
verses.english: 'Therefore, do this: Remove the kings from their positions, each from his own post, and appoint governors in their place.'

verses.latin: Et instaura numerum militum, qui ceciderunt de tuis, et equos secundum equos priores, et currus secundum currus pristinos: et pugnabimus contra eos in campestribus, et videbis quod superabimus eos. Credidit ergo sermonibus eorum, et fecit ita.
verses.english: 'Also, restore the number of soldiers who fell from your ranks, and replace the horses with their former number, and the chariots as they were before. Then we will fight against them on the plains, and you will see that we will surely defeat them.' Ben-Hadad believed their words and acted accordingly.

verses.latin: Igitur annuente tempore, recensuit Benadad Syros, et ascendit in Aphec ut pugnaret contra Israel.
verses.english: So, at the turn of the year, Ben-Hadad assembled the Syrians and went up to Aphek to fight against Israel.

verses.latin: Porro filii Israel recensiti sunt, et assumptis cibariis, profecti sunt obviam illis: et castrametati sunt filii Israel contra eos, quasi duo ovium caularia: Syri autem impleverunt terram.
verses.english: Meanwhile, the sons of Israel were also assembled, and after taking provisions, they marched out to meet them. The sons of Israel encamped opposite them, appearing like two small flocks of goats, while the Syrians filled the entire land.

verses.latin: Et accedens vir Dei ad regem Israel, ait: Hæc dicit Dominus: Quia dixerunt Syri: Deus montium est Dominus, et non est Deus vallium: dabo omnem multitudinem hanc magnam in manu tua, et scietis quia ego Dominus.
verses.english: Then a man of God approached the king of Israel and said: 'The Lord says this: 'Because the Syrians said, 'The Lord is a God of the mountains, and not a God of the valleys,' I will give this entire great multitude into your hand, and you will know that I am the Lord.''

verses.latin: Et septem diebus hi castrametati sunt e regione alterutrum: septima autem die inito certamine, percusserunt filii Israel de Syris centum millia peditum in una die.
verses.english: For seven days, they encamped opposite one another. On the seventh day, the battle began, and the sons of Israel struck down one hundred thousand Syrian foot soldiers in a single day.

verses.latin: Et fugerunt qui reliqui fuerant in Aphec civitatem: et cecidit murus super viginti septem millia virorum qui reliqui fuerant. Benadad autem fugiens ingressus est civitatem in cubiculum intra cubiculum.
verses.english: The remaining Syrian soldiers fled into the city of Aphek. And the city wall collapsed upon the twenty-seven thousand men who had survived. Ben-Hadad, however, fled and entered the city, hiding in an inner chamber within a room.

verses.latin: Dixeruntque ei servi sui: Ecce audivimus reges domus Israel clementes esse: ponamus itaque saccos in lumbis nostris, et funiculos in capitibus nostris, et egrediamur ad regem Israel: forte salvabit animas nostras.
verses.english: His servants said to him: 'Look, we have heard that the kings of the house of Israel are merciful kings. Therefore, let us put on sackcloth around our waists and ropes around our heads, and go out to the king of Israel. Perhaps he will spare our lives.'

verses.latin: Et accinxerunt saccis lumbos suos, et posuerunt funiculos in capitibus suis: veneruntque ad regem Israel, et dixerunt ei: Servus tuus Benadad dicit: Vivat oro te anima mea. Et ille ait: Si adhuc vivit, frater meus est.
verses.english: So they girded sackcloth around their waists and placed ropes around their heads. They came to the king of Israel and said to him: 'Your servant Ben-Hadad says: 'Please let me live!'' And Ahab replied: 'If he is still alive, he is my brother.'

verses.latin: Quod tunc bonum augurium acceperunt viri, et rapuere de ore ejus: atque dixerunt: Frater tuus Benadad. Dixitque eis: Ite, et adducite eum. Exivit ergo Benadad ad eum: et ascendit currum suum.
verses.english: The men took this as a good omen, and seized upon his words, saying: 'Yes, your brother Ben-Hadad is alive!' Ahab then told them: 'Go and bring him here.' So Ben-Hadad came out to him, and Ahab had him get into his own chariot.

verses.latin: Dixitque ei Benadad: Civitates quas pater meus abstulit a patre tuo, reddam: et plateas fac tibi in Damasco, sicut fecit pater meus in Samaria: et ego fœdus inibo tecum, et dimittam te. Perissit ergo Achab cum eo fœdus, et dimisit eum.
verses.english: Ben-Hadad said to him: 'The cities that my father took from your father, I will restore to you. And you may establish marketplaces for yourself in Damascus, just as my father established them in Samaria. I will make a treaty with you, and then I will release you.' So Ahab made a treaty with him and set him free.

verses.latin: Tunc vir quidam de filiis prophetarum dixit socio suo in sermone Domini: Percute me. Et noluit percutere.
verses.english: Then one of the sons of the prophets said to his companion, by the word of the Lord: 'Strike me!' But his companion refused to strike him.

verses.latin: Cui ait: Quia noluisti audire vocem Domini, ecce recedens a me percutiet te leo. Et cum recessisset ab eo, invenit eum leo, et percussit.
verses.english: So the prophet said to him: 'Because you refused to obey the voice of the Lord, behold, as soon as you leave me, a lion will strike you down.' And when he had left the prophet, a lion found him and struck him dead.

verses.latin: Inventum est autem, virum alium de filiis prophetarum, et dixit: Percute me. Percussitque eum homo, et vulneravit.
verses.english: The prophet then found another man from the sons of the prophets and said: 'Strike me!' And that man struck him, wounding him.

verses.latin: Abiit ergo propheta, et occurrit regi in via: et composuit sibi pulverem in facie, et celavit se.
verses.english: So the prophet went and waited for the king by the roadside. He disguised himself by putting dust on his face and covering his eyes and forehead, hiding his identity.

verses.latin: Cumque transiret rex, clamavit ad regem, dicens: Servus tuus egressus est ad pugnam: et cum declinaret homo, et adduxisset hominem ad me, ait mihi: Custodi virum istum: et si quolibet modo evaserit, reddes animam tuam pro anima ejus, aut talentum argenti appendes.
verses.english: As the king passed by, the prophet cried out to him, saying: 'Your servant went out into the midst of the battle. And when a man turned aside and brought another man to me, he said to me: 'Guard this man. If he escapes in any way, you will forfeit your own life for his life, or you will weigh out a talent of silver.''

verses.latin: Dum autem servus tuus occupatur huc atque illuc, ille subito non comparuit. Et ait rex Israel: Hoc est judicium tuum, quod ipse decrevisti.
verses.english: 'While your servant was busy here and there, the man suddenly disappeared.' The king of Israel said to him: 'This is your judgment, which you yourself have decided.'

verses.latin: Benadad itaque rex Syriae congregavit omnem exercitum suum: et triginta duo reges cum eo, et equos, et currus: et ascendens obsedit Samariam, et pugnabat contra eam.
verses.english: So Ben-Hadad, the king of Syria, gathered his entire army. He had thirty-two other kings with him, along with their cavalry forces and chariots. They advanced, besieged Samaria, and began to wage war against it.

verses.latin: Mittensque nuntios ad Achab regem Israel in civitatem,
verses.english: He sent messengers into the city to Ahab, the king of Israel,

verses.latin: ait: Hæc dicit Benadad: Argentum tuum, et aurum tuum meum est: et uxores tuas optimas, et filios tuos meos habe.
verses.english: saying: "Ben-Hadad declares this: All your silver and all your gold are mine. Your finest wives and your children are also mine."

verses.latin: Responditque rex Israel: Juxta verbum tuum, domine mi rex, tuus sum ego, et omnia mea.
verses.english: The king of Israel responded: "As you have said, my lord king, I am your servant, and all that I have is yours."

verses.latin: Reversusque nuntius, ait ei: Hæc dicit Benadad: Misi ad te, dicens: Argentum tuum, et aurum tuum, et uxores tuas, et filios tuos dabis mihi.
verses.english: But the messenger returned again and said to Ahab: "Ben-Hadad declares this: I sent word to you saying, 'You must give me your silver, your gold, your wives, and your children.'

verses.latin: Cras igitur hac hora mittam servos meos ad te, et scrutabuntur domos tuas, et thesauros servorum tuorum: et omne quod eis placuerit, tollent, et asportabunt.
verses.english: Therefore, tomorrow at this time, I will send my servants to you. They will search through your palace and the treasuries of your officials. Everything that seems desirable to them, they will take and carry away."

verses.latin: Et convocavit Achab omnes seniores terræ, et ait: Animadvertite, et videte quod insidietur nobis. Nam cum misisset ad me de uxoribus meis, et filiis meis, et argento, et auro, non negavi.
verses.english: Then Ahab summoned all the elders of the land and said: "Notice and consider how this man is plotting against us. For when he sent for my wives, my children, my silver, and my gold, I did not refuse him."

verses.latin: Dixeruntque omnes majores, et universus populus illi: Noli adquiescere, neque audias.
verses.english: All the elders and all the people told him: "Do not consent, nor listen to his demand."

verses.latin: Respondit ergo nuntiis Benadad: Dicite domino meo regi: Omne quod primum misisti ad me servum tuum, faciam: hoc autem facere non possum. Reversique nuntii, retulerunt ei.
verses.english: So Ahab replied to Ben-Hadad’s messengers: "Tell my lord the king: Everything that you first demanded from your servant, I will do. But this latest demand, I cannot fulfill." The messengers returned and reported this to Ben-Hadad.

verses.latin: Misitque ad eum Benadad, dicens: Hæc faciant mihi dii, et hæc addant, si suffecerit pulvis Samariæ pugillis omnium populorum qui sequuntur me.
verses.english: Then Ben-Hadad sent word to Ahab, saying: "May the gods deal with me, and add even more punishments, if there is enough dust in Samaria for each of my followers to fill their hands! This means Samaria will be utterly destroyed by my vast army."

verses.latin: Et respondens rex Israel, ait: Dicite: Non glorietur accinctus, æque ut discinctus.
verses.english: The king of Israel replied: "Tell him this proverb: 'Let not the one who puts on his armor boast as much as the one who takes it off.' In other words, don't boast before the battle is won."

verses.latin: Factum est ergo, cum audisset Benadad sermonem hunc, bibens ipse et reges in tabernaculis, et ait servis suis: Circumdate civitatem. Et circumdederunt urbem.
verses.english: When Ben-Hadad heard this message, he was drinking with the other kings in their tents. He then ordered his servants: "Surround the city!" So they began to besiege the city.

verses.latin: Et ecce propheta accedent ad Achab regem Israel, ait: Hæc dicit Dominus: Vidistine omnem multitudinem hanc nimiam? Ecce ego tradam illam in manu tua hodie: et scies quia ego sum Dominus.
verses.english: Then, a prophet approached Ahab, the king of Israel, and declared: "Thus says the Lord God: 'Have you seen this vast multitude? Behold, I will deliver them into your hand today, so that you may know that I am the Lord God.'"

verses.latin: Et ait Achab: Per quos? Dixitque illi: Hæc dicit Dominus: Per pedisequos principum provinciarum. Et ait: Quis incipiet mittere? Et ille dixit: Tu.
verses.english: Ahab asked: "By whom will you do this?" The prophet replied: "Thus says the Lord God: 'By the young men who serve the provincial governors.'" Ahab then asked: "Who will begin the attack?" The prophet answered: "You, yourself."

verses.latin: Numeravit ergo Achab pedisequos principum provinciarum, et repperit ducentos triginta duos: post hos recensuit universum populum, filios Israel, septem millia.
verses.english: So Ahab counted the young men who served the provincial governors, and there were two hundred and thirty-two of them. After them, he numbered all the people, the sons of Israel, who were seven thousand strong.

verses.latin: Et egressi sunt meridie. Benadad autem bibebat temulentus in tabernaculo suo, et reges triginta duo cum eo, qui ad auxilium ejus venerant.
verses.english: They marched out at noon. Meanwhile, Ben-Hadad and the thirty-two kings who had come to assist him were drinking themselves drunk in their tents.

verses.latin: Egressique sunt pedisequi principum provinciarum primi. Misit ergo Benadad: qui nuntiaverunt ei, dicentes: Viri egressi sunt de Samaria.
verses.english: The young men of the provincial governors went out first. Ben-Hadad sent out scouts, who reported back to him, saying: "Some men have come out of Samaria!"

verses.latin: At ille ait: Sive pro pace venerunt, apprehendite eos vivos: sive ut pugnent, vivos capite.
verses.english: He commanded: "Whether they have come out to seek peace, capture them alive. Or if they have come out to fight, capture them alive as well!"

verses.latin: Egressi sunt ergo juvenes principum provinciarum, et exercitus post eos.
verses.english: So the young men of the provincial governors went out, and the rest of the Israelite army followed behind them.

verses.latin: Et percusserunt unusquisque virum qui obvius ei fuerat: fugeruntque Syri, et persecutus est eos Israel. Fugit quoque Benadad rex Syriae in equo, et equites cum eo.
verses.english: Each one struck down the man who confronted him. The Syrians fled, and Israel pursued them. Ben-Hadad, the king of Syria, also fled on horseback with his cavalry.

verses.latin: Egressus ergo rex Israel, percussit equos et currus: et percussit Syriam plaga magna.
verses.english: The king of Israel went out and struck down the Syrian horses and chariots, inflicting a great defeat upon Syria.

verses.latin: Accedens autem propheta ad regem Israel, ait illi: Vade, et confortare, et scito, et vide quid facias: eo quod annus revolvatur, et rex Syriae ascendat contra te.
verses.english: Then the prophet came to the king of Israel and told him: "Go now, strengthen your forces, take note, and consider what you must do, because at the turn of the year, the king of Syria will come up against you again."

verses.latin: Servi vero regis Syriae dixerunt ei: Dii montium sunt dii eorum, ideo superaverunt nos: sed melius est ut pugnemus contra eos in campestribus, et superabimus eos.
verses.english: But the servants of the king of Syria said to him: "Their gods are gods of the mountains; that is why they have overpowered us. But it is better that we fight against them on the plains, and then we will surely defeat them."

verses.latin: Tu quoque hoc consilium incipe, et amove reges singulos ab exercitu tuo, et pone principes pro eis:
verses.english: Take this counsel: Remove all the kings from their positions in your army, and appoint commanders in their place.

verses.latin: Et instaura numerum militum qui ceciderunt de tuis, et equos secundum equos priores, et currus secundum currus quos habuisti: et pugnabimus contra eos in campestribus, et videbis quod obtinebimus. Credidit ergo consilio eorum, et fecit ita.
verses.english: Then, restore the number of soldiers that you lost, and replace the horses with new horses, and the chariots with new chariots, just as you had before. We will fight against them on the plains, and you will see that we will surely prevail." Ben-Hadad trusted their advice and acted accordingly.

verses.latin: Igitur post annos, recensuit Benadad Syros, et ascendit in Aphec ad pugnandum contra Israel.
verses.english: So, after a year had passed, Ben-Hadad mustered the Syrians and went up to Aphek to fight against Israel.

verses.latin: Porro filii Israel recensiti sunt, et assumptis cibariis, profecti ex adverso. Castrametati sunt filii Israel contra eos, quasi duo greges caprarum: Syri autem repleverunt superficiem terræ.
verses.english: Meanwhile, the sons of Israel were also mustered. They took provisions and marched out to confront the Syrians. The sons of Israel encamped opposite them, looking like two small flocks of goats, while the Syrians completely covered the surface of the land.

verses.latin: Accedens autem vir Dei ad regem Israel, ait: Hæc dicit Dominus: Eo quod dixerint Syri: Deus montium est Dominus, et non est Deus vallium, dabo omnem multitudinem hanc magnam in manu tua, et scietis quia ego Dominus.
verses.english: Then a man of God approached the king of Israel and declared: "Thus says the Lord God: 'Because the Syrians have said, 'The Lord is a god of the mountains, but not a god of the valleys,' I will deliver this entire vast multitude into your hand. Then you will know that I am the Lord God.'"

verses.latin: Et castrametati sunt septem diebus hi ex adverso illorum. Septima autem die commissum est bellum: et percusserunt filii Israel de Syris centum millia peditum in una die.
verses.english: They encamped opposite one another for seven days. On the seventh day, the battle began. And the sons of Israel struck down one hundred thousand Syrian foot soldiers in a single day.

verses.latin: Fugerunt autem qui reliqui fuerant in civitatem Aphec: et cecidit murus super viginti septem millia hominum, qui residui fuerant. Benadad autem fugiens ingressus est civitatem, in cubiculum intra cubiculum.
verses.english: Those who remained alive fled into the city of Aphek, but the wall collapsed upon twenty-seven thousand of the remaining men. Ben-Hadad, however, fled and entered the city, hiding in an inner chamber within a room.

verses.latin: Dixeruntque ei servi sui: Ecce audivimus quia reges domus Israel clementes sunt: ponamus ergo saccos in lumbis nostris, et funiculos in capitibus nostris, et egrediamur ad regem Israel: forsitan salvabit animas nostras.
verses.english: His servants said to him: "Behold, we have heard that the kings of the house of Israel are merciful. Let us, therefore, put sackcloth around our waists and ropes upon our heads, and go out to the king of Israel. Perhaps he will spare our lives."

verses.latin: Cinxerunt ergo se saccis in lumbis suis, et funibus in capitibus suis venerunt ad regem Israel, et dixerunt ei: Servus tuus Benadad dicit: Vivat, oro te, anima mea.
verses.english: So they girded themselves with sackcloth around their waists and ropes upon their heads. They came to the king of Israel and said to him: "Your servant Ben-Hadad says: 'Please, let my life be spared.'"

verses.latin: Et ille ait: Si adhuc vivit, frater meus est. Porro viri prognosticaverant, et raptim verbum acceperunt ab ore ejus, atque dixerunt: Frater tuus Benadad.
verses.english: Ahab replied: "If he is still alive, he is my brother." The men took this as a favorable sign and quickly seized upon his word, confirming: "Indeed! Your brother Ben-Hadad!"

verses.latin: Et ait: Ite, et adducite eum. Egressus est ergo Benadad ad eum, et ascendit in currum suum.
verses.english: Ahab then commanded: "Go and bring him here." So Ben-Hadad came out to him, and Ahab invited him to step into his own chariot.

verses.latin: Dixitque illi Benadad: Civitates quas pater meus tulit a patre tuo, reddam: et vicos fac tibi in Damasco, sicut fecit pater meus in Samaria, et fœdus firmabo tecum. Et ait illi Achab: Ego igitur foedus inibo tecum, et dimittam te. Percussit ergo cum eo fœdus, et dimisit eum.
verses.english: Ben-Hadad then said to him: "The cities that my father took from your father, I will restore. You may also establish marketplaces for yourself in Damascus, just as my father established them in Samaria. I will make a treaty with you." Ahab replied: "Therefore, I will make a treaty with you and then release you." So Ahab made a treaty with Ben-Hadad and set him free.

verses.latin: Tunc vir quidam de filiis prophetarum ait socio suo in sermone Domini: Percute me. Qui noluit percutere.
verses.english: At that time, a certain man from among the sons of the prophets said to his companion, by the word of the Lord: "Strike me!" But his companion refused to strike him.

verses.latin: Et ait illi: Quia noluisti audire vocem Domini, ecce dimittes me, et percutiet te leo. Et cum recessisset ab eo, invenit eum leo, et percussit.
verses.english: So the prophet said to him: "Because you refused to obey the voice of the Lord, behold, as soon as you leave me, a lion will strike you down." And when he departed from him, a lion found him and struck him down.

verses.latin: Invenit quoque alterum virum, et ait: Percute me. Qui percussit eum, et vulneravit.
verses.english: He then found another man and said: "Strike me!" And this man struck him and wounded him severely.

verses.latin: Abiit ergo propheta, et occurrit regi in via, et simulavit se esse vulneratum cinere in facie et oculis suis.
verses.english: So the prophet went and waited for the king by the road, disguising himself with ashes on his face and over his eyes to appear wounded.

verses.latin: Cumque rex transiret, clamavit ad regem, et ait: Servus tuus egressus est ad pugnandum cominus: et ecce vir aversus adduxit ad me hominem, et ait: Custodi virum istum: et si lapsus fuerit, reddes animam ejus pro anima ejus: aut talentum argenti appendes.
verses.english: As the king passed by, the prophet called out to him and said: "Your servant went out to the front lines of the battle, and behold, a man turned aside and brought a prisoner to me, saying: 'Guard this man. If he escapes, you shall pay with your own life for his life, or else you must pay a talent of silver.'"

verses.latin: Post haec, accidit tempus illud: Naboth Jezrahelites possidebat vineam juxta palatium Achab regis Samariae.
verses.english: After these events, a certain time came to pass: Naboth, from Jezreel, owned a vineyard which was next to the royal palace of King Ahab, who reigned in Samaria.

verses.latin: Locutus est ergo Achab ad Naboth, dicens: Da mihi vineam tuam ut faciam mihi hortum olerum, quia vicina est domui meae: et dabo tibi pro ea vineam meliorem; aut si tibi commodius videtur, pretium argenti quod valet, dabo tibi.
verses.english: So King Ahab spoke to Naboth, saying to him: 'Give me your vineyard, so I can make it into a vegetable garden for myself, because it's so close to my royal house. I will give you a better vineyard for it, or, if you prefer, I will pay you its worth in silver.'

verses.latin: Cui respondit Naboth: Propitius sit mihi Dominus, ne dem hereditatem patrum meorum tibi.
verses.english: But Naboth answered him: 'May the Lord be merciful to me! I will not give you the inheritance I received from my ancestors.'

verses.latin: Venit ergo Achab in domum suam tristis et indignans super verbo, quod locutus fuerat Naboth Jezrahelites, dicens: Non dabo tibi hereditatem patrum meorum. Et projecit se in lectulum suum, avertitque faciem suam ad parietem, et non comedit panem.
verses.english: So Ahab returned to his house, gloomy and indignant because of the words Naboth the Jezreelite had said: 'I will not give you the inheritance from my fathers.' He threw himself onto his bed, turned his face toward the wall, and refused to eat any food.

verses.latin: Ingressa est itaque ad eum Jezabel uxor sua, et ait illi: Quid est hoc, quod anima tua tristis est, et non comedis panem?
verses.english: Then Jezebel, his wife, came in to him and said to him: 'What is this, that your spirit is so sad, and you are not eating any food?'

verses.latin: Qui respondit ei: Locutus sum ad Naboth Jezrahelitem, et dixi ei: Da mihi vineam tuam accepta pecunia, aut si tibi placet, dabo tibi vineam pro ea. Et ille ait: Non dabo tibi vineam meam.
verses.english: He answered her: 'I spoke to Naboth the Jezreelite and said to him: 'Give me your vineyard for money, or if you prefer, I will give you another vineyard in its place.' But he said, 'I will not give you my vineyard.'

verses.latin: Dixit ergo ad eum Jezabel: Tu nunc fidenter regnas in Israel. Surge, et comede panem, et aequo esto animo: ego enim dabo tibi vineam Naboth Jezrahelitae.
verses.english: Then Jezebel said to him: 'Are you truly reigning as king over Israel with confidence right now? Get up, eat your food, and cheer up! For I will certainly give you the vineyard of Naboth the Jezreelite!'

verses.latin: Scripsit ergo litteras nomine Achab, et signavit eas anulo ejus, et misit ad majores natu et ad optimates, qui erant in civitate ejus et habitabant cum Naboth.
verses.english: So Jezebel wrote letters in Ahab's name and sealed them with his royal signet ring. She then sent these letters to the elders and nobles, who lived in Naboth's city and with him.

verses.latin: Et sic scripsit in litteris: Praedicate jejunium, et sedere facite Naboth in primis populi:
verses.english: And this is what she wrote in the letters: 'Proclaim a fast, and seat Naboth in a prominent place among the people.'

verses.latin: et ponite viros filios Belial contra eum, qui testificentur: Maledixit Deo et regi. Et extrahentes eum, lapidate, et moriatur.
verses.english: 'Then bring two worthless men, 'sons of Belial,' to accuse him, who will testify against him, saying: 'He cursed God and the king!' Then take him outside the city, stone him to death, and let him die.'

verses.latin: Fecerunt ergo viri civitatis ejus, majores natu et optimates, qui habitabant cum eo in civitate, sicut praeceperat eis Jezabel, et ut scriptum erat in litteris, quas miserat ad eos:
verses.english: So the men of Naboth's city—the elders and nobles who lived there with him—did as Jezebel had commanded them, just as it was written in the letters she had sent to them.

verses.latin: Praedicaverunt jejunium, et sedere fecerunt Naboth in primis populi.
verses.english: They proclaimed a fast, and they seated Naboth in a prominent place among the people.

verses.latin: Et adductis duobus viris filiis Belial, fecerunt eos sedere contra eum: qui testati sunt contra eum coram multitudine: Maledixit Naboth Deo et regi. Et extraxerunt eum extra civitatem, et lapidibus interfecerunt.
verses.english: Then two worthless men, 'sons of Belial,' were brought in and seated opposite him. They testified against him before the assembled crowd, saying: 'Naboth cursed God and the king!' So they dragged him outside the city and killed him with stones.

verses.latin: Miseruntque ad Jezabel, dicentes: Lapidatus est Naboth, et mortuus est.
verses.english: Then they sent a message to Jezebel, saying: 'Naboth has been stoned, and he is dead.'

verses.latin: Cum audisset autem Jezabel lapidatum Naboth et mortuum, locuta est ad Achab, dicens: Surge, posside vineam Naboth Jezrahelitae, qui noluit tibi acquiescere, et dare tibi eam accepta pecunia: non enim vivit Naboth, sed mortuus est.
verses.english: When Jezebel heard that Naboth had been stoned to death, she spoke to Ahab, saying: 'Get up, and take possession of the vineyard of Naboth the Jezreelite, who refused to agree with you and give it to you for money. For Naboth is no longer alive; he is dead.'

verses.latin: Quod cum audisset Achab, quod mortuus esset Naboth, surrexit, et descendit in vineam Naboth Jezrahelitae, ut possideret eam.
verses.english: When Ahab heard that Naboth was dead, he got up and went down to the vineyard of Naboth the Jezreelite, so that he could take possession of it.

verses.latin: Factum est autem verbum Domini ad Eliam Thesbiten, dicens:
verses.english: Now the word of the Lord came to Elijah the Tishbite, saying:

verses.latin: Surge, et descende in occursum Achab regis Israel, qui est in Samaria: ecce in vinea Naboth, ad quam descendit ut possideat eam.
verses.english: 'Get up and go down to meet Ahab, the king of Israel, who is in Samaria. Look, he is in Naboth's vineyard, where he has gone down to take possession of it.'

verses.latin: Et loqueris ad eum, dicens: Haec dicit Dominus: Occidisti, insuper et possedisti? Et post haec addes: Haec dicit Dominus: In loco isto in quo linxerunt canes sanguinem Naboth, lambent et tuum sanguinem.
verses.english: 'And you shall speak to him, saying: 'Thus says the Lord: 'Have you murdered, and then also taken possession?' And then you shall add: 'Thus says the Lord: 'In this very place where dogs licked up Naboth's blood, there will dogs also lick up your blood—yours, King Ahab!''

verses.latin: Et ait Achab ad Eliam: Num invenisti me, inimice mi? Et ille ait: Inveni, eo quod venundatus sis ut faceres malum in conspectu Domini.
verses.english: And Ahab said to Elijah: 'Have you found me, my enemy?' Elijah replied: 'I have found you, because you have sold yourself to do evil in the sight of the Lord.'

verses.latin: Ecce ego inducam super te malum, et demetam reliquias tuas, et interficiam de Achab mingentem ad parietem, et clausum, et ultimum in Israel.
verses.english: 'Behold, I will bring disaster upon you, and I will utterly sweep away your descendants, and I will cut off from Ahab every male, even the lowest, a 'pisser against a wall', both bond and free, every last one in Israel.'

verses.latin: Et faciam domum tuam sicut domum Jeroboam filii Nabat, et sicut domum Baasa filii Ahia, propter id quod irritasti, et peccare fecisti Israel.
verses.english: 'And I will make your house like the house of Jeroboam, the son of Nebat, and like the house of Baasha, the son of Ahijah, because you have provoked Me to anger and have made Israel sin.'

verses.latin: Sed et de Jezabel locutus est Dominus, dicens: Canes comedent Jezabel in agro Jezrahel.
verses.english: 'Concerning Jezebel also, the Lord has spoken, saying: 'Dogs will devour Jezebel in the open field near Jezreel.'

verses.latin: Si quis de Achab mortuus fuerit in civitate, comedent eum canes: si autem mortuus fuerit in agro, comedent eum volucres caeli.
verses.english: 'If any of Ahab's family dies within the city, dogs will eat him. But if any of them dies in the open country, the birds of the sky will eat him.'

verses.latin: Igitur non fuit alter talis ut Achab, qui venundatus est ut faceret malum in conspectu Domini: instigavit enim eum Jezabel uxor sua.
verses.english: Indeed, there was no one like Ahab, who had sold himself to do evil in the sight of the Lord; for his wife, Jezebel, incited him and drove him to it.

verses.latin: Et abominabilis factus est, eo quod sequeretur idola, et operaretur cuncta quae fecerant Amorrhaei, quos consumpsit Dominus a facie filiorum Israel.
verses.english: He became truly abominable because he followed idols, and he practiced all the detestable things that the Amorites had done, whom the Lord had destroyed and removed from the presence of the children of Israel.

verses.latin: Itaque cum audisset Achab sermones istos, scidit vestimenta sua, et operuit cilicio carnem suam, jejunavitque, et dormivit in sacco, et ambulabat demisso capite.
verses.english: Now when Ahab heard these words, he tore his clothes, and he put on sackcloth over his skin, and he fasted, and he slept in sackcloth, and he walked around with a bowed head.

verses.latin: Factum est autem verbum Domini ad Eliam Thesbiten, dicens:
verses.english: And the word of the Lord came to Elijah the Tishbite, saying:

verses.latin: Vidistine Achab humiliatum coram me? quia igitur humiliatus est mei causa, non inducam malum in diebus ejus, sed in diebus filii ejus inducam malum super domum ejus.
verses.english: 'Have you seen how Ahab has humbled himself before Me? Because he has humbled himself on My account, I will not bring this disaster in his own lifetime, but in the days of his son, I will bring the disaster upon his house.'
