verses.latin: Post haec accidit ut Naboth Jezrahelita possideret vineam in Jezrahel juxta palatium Achab regis Samariae.
verses.english: Some time after these events, Naboth, a man from Jezreel, owned a vineyard in Jezreel, right next to the palace of Ahab, the king who ruled Samaria.

verses.latin: Locutus est ergo Achab ad Naboth dicens: Da mihi vineam tuam ut faciam mihi hortum olerum, quia vicina est et prope domum meam: daboque tibi pro ea vineam meliorem, aut si tibi placuerit, argenti pretium quantum valet.
verses.english: So King Ahab spoke to Naboth, saying: "Give me your vineyard so I can turn it into a vegetable garden, because it is very close to my palace. In exchange, I will give you either a better vineyard, or, if you prefer, I will pay you its full value in silver."

verses.latin: Cui respondit Naboth: Propitius sit mihi Dominus, ne dem hereditatem patrum meorum tibi.
verses.english: Naboth replied to him, saying: "May the Lord forbid me from ever giving you the inheritance of my ancestors." The ancestral land was a sacred trust, not to be sold outside the family.

verses.latin: Venit ergo Achab in domum suam tristis et indignans super verbo quod locutus fuerat Naboth Jezrahelita dicens: Non do tibi hereditatem patrum meorum. Et projiciens se in lectulum suum avertit faciem suam ad parietem, et non comedit panem.
verses.english: So Ahab went home, sad and indignant because of what Naboth the Jezreelite had said: "I will not give you the inheritance of my ancestors." King Ahab then threw himself onto his bed, turning his face to the wall, and refused to eat anything.

verses.latin: Ingressa est autem ad eum Jezabel uxor sua, dixitque illi: Quid est hoc, cur tristis est animus tuus, et quare non comedis panem?
verses.english: Then his wife Jezebel came in to him and asked: "Why are you so sad? Why aren't you eating anything?"

verses.latin: Qui respondit ei: Locutus sum ad Naboth Jezrahelitam, et dixi illi: Da mihi vineam tuam accepta pecunia: aut si placet tibi, dabo tibi vineam pro ea meliorem. Et ille respondit: Non dabo tibi vineam meam.
verses.english: He answered her: "I spoke to Naboth the Jezreelite and said to him: 'Give me your vineyard for money, or if you prefer, I will give you a better vineyard in exchange.' But he replied: 'I will not give you my vineyard.'"

verses.latin: Dixit ergo ad eum Jezabel uxor ejus: Tu nunc magnanimus est, et facis regnum Israel? Surge, et comede panem, et aequo esto animo: ego dabo tibi vineam Naboth Jezrahelitae.
verses.english: Then his wife Jezebel said to him: "Are you really the great king of Israel? Get up, eat something, and cheer up! I will personally make sure you get the vineyard of Naboth the Jezreelite."

verses.latin: Scripsit ergo litteras nomine Achab, et signavit eas annulo ejus, et misit ad majores natu, et ad optimates, qui erant in civitate ejus et habitabant cum Naboth.
verses.english: So Jezebel wrote letters in Ahab's name, sealed them with his royal signet ring, and sent them to the elders and nobles who lived in Naboth's city and who knew him.

verses.latin: Et addidit in epistolis: Praedicate jejunium, et sedere facite Naboth in primis.
verses.english: In these letters, she commanded: "Declare a public fast, and make sure Naboth is seated prominently among the people." A fast was often called in times of public distress or when investigating a serious sin, setting the stage for a false accusation.

verses.latin: Et ponite duos viros filios Belial contra eum, qui testificentur: Benedixit Deo, et regi: et educite eum, et lapidate, et moriatur.
verses.english: "Then, bring two wicked men—sons of Belial, meaning utterly worthless men—to testify against him, saying: 'You blasphemed God and the king!' After their testimony, take him outside the city, stone him to death, and ensure he dies."

verses.latin: Fecerunt ergo cives ejus, majores natu et optimates qui habitabant in civitate ejus, sicut praeceperat eis Jezabel, et sicut scriptum erat in litteris quas miserat ad eos.
verses.english: The citizens of Jezreel, including the elders and nobles who lived in Naboth's city, did exactly as Jezebel had commanded them and as it was written in the letters she had sent.

verses.latin: Praedicaverunt jejunium, et sedere fecerunt Naboth in primis.
verses.english: They declared a public fast and seated Naboth prominently among the people.

verses.latin: Et adductis duobus viris filios diaboli, fecerunt eos sedere contra eum: qui et testificati sunt adversus eum coram multitudine, dicentes: Benedixit Naboth Deo et regi. Quam ob rem eduxerunt eum extra civitatem, et lapidibus interfecerunt.
verses.english: Then the two evil men, those wicked sons of the devil, were brought in and made to sit opposite Naboth. They testified against him before all the people, falsely declaring: "Naboth blasphemed God and the king!" Because of this false accusation, they dragged him outside the city and stoned him to death.

verses.latin: Mandaveruntque ad Jezabel dicentes: Lapidatus est Naboth, et mortuus est.
verses.english: They then sent word to Jezebel, saying: "Naboth has been stoned, and he is dead."

verses.latin: Cum audisset autem Jezabel lapidatum Naboth et mortuum, locuta est ad Achab dicens: Surge, posside vineam Naboth Jezrahelitae, qui noluit tibi acquiescere, et dare tibi pro pecunia: non enim vivit Naboth, sed mortuus est.
verses.english: When Jezebel heard that Naboth had been stoned and was dead, she said to Ahab: "Get up, go and take possession of the vineyard of Naboth the Jezreelite, the one who refused to give it to you for money. For Naboth is no longer alive; he is dead."

verses.latin: Quod cum audisset Achab, surrexit, et descendit in vineam Naboth Jezrahelitae, ut possideret eam.
verses.english: As soon as Ahab heard this, he got up and went down to the vineyard of Naboth the Jezreelite, intending to take possession of it.

verses.latin: Factum est ergo verbum Domini ad Eliam Thesbiten, dicens:
verses.english: Then the word of the Lord came to Elijah the Tishbite, saying:

verses.latin: Surge, et descende in occursum Achab regis Israel, qui est in Samaria: ecce in vinea Naboth, ad quam descendit ut possideat eam.
verses.english: "Go now, and meet Ahab, the king of Israel who lives in Samaria. Look, you will find him in Naboth's vineyard, where he has gone down to take possession of it."

verses.latin: Et loqueris ad eum, dicens: Haec dicit Dominus: Occidisti, quoque possedisti? Et post haec adicies: In loco in quo linxerunt canes sanguinem Naboth, ibi lambent tuum quoque sanguinem.
verses.english: "And you shall speak to him, saying: 'Thus says the Lord: Have you not both committed murder and seized possession? And beyond this, you must add: In the very place where dogs licked up the blood of Naboth, there also shall dogs lick up your blood.'"

verses.latin: Et dixit Achab ad Eliam: Num invenisti me, inimice mihi? Qui dixit: Inveni, eo quod venundatus sis ut faceres malum in conspectu Domini.
verses.english: Ahab said to Elijah: "Have you found me, my enemy?" Elijah replied: "Yes, I have found you, because you have completely sold yourself out to do evil in the sight of the Lord."

verses.latin: Ecce ego inducam super te malum, et demetam posteriora tua, et interficiam de Achab mingentem ad parietem, et clausum, et novissimum in Israel.
verses.english: "Behold, I will bring disaster upon you. I will utterly sweep away your descendants, and I will cut off from Ahab every male in Israel—both slave and free, the weakest and the strongest—leaving no one."

verses.latin: Et faciam domum tuam sicut domum Jeroboam filii Nabat, et sicut domum Baasa filii Ahia: propter id quod concitasti, ut peccaret Israel, et concitasti me ad iracundiam.
verses.english: "And I will make your house like the house of Jeroboam, son of Nebat, and like the house of Baasha, son of Ahijah: because you have provoked me to anger and have caused Israel to sin."

verses.latin: Sed et de Jezabel locutus est Dominus, dicens: Canes comedent Jezabel in agro Jezrahel.
verses.english: "Moreover, concerning Jezebel, the Lord has spoken, saying: 'Dogs shall devour Jezebel in the open field of Jezreel.'"

verses.latin: Si quis mortuus fuerit de Achab in civitate, comedent eum canes: si autem mortuus fuerit in agro, vorabunt eum volucres caeli.
verses.english: "If any of Ahab's family dies within the city, dogs will eat his body. If any of them dies in the open country, the birds of the sky will devour his body."

verses.latin: Igitur non fuit alter talis sicut Achab, qui venundatus est ut faceret malum in conspectu Domini: concitavit enim eum Jezabel uxor sua.
verses.english: Indeed, there was no one else like Ahab, who completely sold himself to do evil in the sight of the Lord; his wife Jezebel constantly incited him to do so.

verses.latin: Et abominabilis factus est, eo quod sequeretur idola, quae fecerant Amorrhaei, quos consumpsit Dominus a facie filiorum Israel.
verses.english: He became utterly detestable, because he followed idols, just as the Amorites had done—those whom the Lord had destroyed from the presence of the children of Israel.

verses.latin: Itaque cum audisset Achab sermones istos, scidit vestimenta sua, et operuit cilicio carnem suam, jejunavitque, et dormivit in sacco, et ambulabat demisso capite.
verses.english: When Ahab heard these words, he tore his clothes, put sackcloth directly over his bare skin, fasted, and even slept in sackcloth. He walked about with his head bowed down in deep humility and sorrow.

verses.latin: Factum est ergo verbum Domini ad Eliam Thesbiten, dicens:
verses.english: Then the word of the Lord came to Elijah the Tishbite, saying:

verses.latin: Nonne vidisti humiliatum Achab coram me? Igitur quia humiliatus est mei causa, non inducam malum in diebus ejus: sed in diebus filii ejus inducam malum super domum ejus.
verses.english: "Have you not seen how Ahab has humbled himself before me? Therefore, because he has humbled himself for my sake, I will not bring this disaster in his own lifetime. Instead, I will bring the disaster upon his household in the days of his son."

verses.latin: Post haec, accidit tempus, ut Naboth Jezrahelites possideret vineam juxta palatium Achab regis Samariae.
verses.english: After these events, it came to pass that Naboth the Jezreelite owned a vineyard near the palace of Ahab, king of Samaria.

verses.latin: Locutus est ergo Achab ad Naboth, dicens: Da mihi vineam tuam, ut faciam mihi hortum olerum, quia vicina est, et prope domum meam: et dabo tibi pro ea vineam meliorem: aut si tibi commodius videtur, pretium emam a te argenti.
verses.english: So King Ahab spoke to Naboth, saying: 'Give me your vineyard, so I can make a vegetable garden there, because it is close and near my own house. In exchange, I will give you a better vineyard; or, if it seems more convenient to you, I will buy it from you for its price in silver.'

verses.latin: Cui respondit Naboth: Propitius sit mihi Dominus, ne dem hereditatem patrum meorum tibi.
verses.english: But Naboth answered him: 'May the Lord forbid me from giving you the inheritance of my fathers.'

verses.latin: Venit ergo Achab in domum suam iratus, et indignans super verbo, quod locutus fuerat ad eum Naboth Jezrahelites, dicens: Non dabo tibi hereditatem patrum meorum. Et projecit se in lectulum suum, avertitque faciem suam ad parietem, et non comedit panem.
verses.english: So Ahab came into his house, angry and indignant because of the refusal Naboth the Jezreelite had given him, saying: 'I will not give you the inheritance of my fathers.' And he threw himself onto his bed, turned his face to the wall, and refused to eat any food.

verses.latin: Ingressa est ad eum Jezabel uxor sua, et dixit illi: Quid est hoc, quod anima tua contristata est, et non comederis panem?
verses.english: His wife Jezebel came in to him and said: 'Why is your spirit so troubled, and why are you refusing to eat food?'

verses.latin: Qui respondit ei: Locutus sum Naboth Jezrahelitae, et dixi illi: Da mihi vineam tuam pecunia: aut si placet tibi, dabo tibi vineam pro ea meliorem. Et ille respondit: Non dabo tibi vineam meam.
verses.english: He answered her: 'I spoke to Naboth the Jezreelite, and I said to him: "Give me your vineyard for money; or if you prefer, I will give you a better vineyard in exchange." But he answered: "I will not give you my vineyard."'

verses.latin: Dixit itaque ad eum Jezabel uxor sua: Major es tu, et facis hoc in regno Israel? Surge, et comede panem, et esto bono animo: ego vindicabo tibi vineam Naboth Jezrahelitae.
verses.english: So Jezebel his wife said to him: 'Are you the King of Israel, and you allow yourself to act this way? Get up, eat your food, and be cheerful! I will secure for you the vineyard of Naboth the Jezreelite.'

verses.latin: Scripsit ergo litteras nomine Achab, et signavit eas annulo ejus: et misit ad majores natu, et ad optimates qui erant in civitate ejus, et habitabant cum Naboth.
verses.english: So she wrote letters in Ahab's name and sealed them with his signet ring. She sent them to the elders and to the nobles who lived in Naboth's city and resided with him.

verses.latin: Et hæc scripsit in litteris: Prædicate jejunium, et sedere facite Naboth in primis populi:
verses.english: And she wrote this in the letters: 'Proclaim a fast, and make Naboth sit in a prominent place among the people;'

verses.latin: et ponite viros duos filios Belial contra eum, qui loquantur testimonium falsum: Dixisti maledicens Deo et regi: et educite eum, et lapidate, et moriatur.
verses.english: 'and set two men, worthless scoundrels, against him to give false testimony and say: "You cursed God and the king!" Then, take him outside, stone him to death, and let him die.'

verses.latin: Fecerunt ergo viri civitatis ejus, majores natu et optimates qui habitabant cum eo in civitate, sicut præceperat eis Jezabel, et ut scriptum erat in litteris quas miserat ad eos:
verses.english: So the men of his city, the elders and the nobles who lived with him in the city, did as Jezebel had commanded them and as it was written in the letters she had sent to them.

verses.latin: prædicaverunt jejunium, et sedere fecerunt Naboth in primis populi.
verses.english: They proclaimed a fast and made Naboth sit in a prominent place among the people.

verses.latin: Adduxeruntque duos viros filios Belial, qui sedentes contra eum, locuti sunt testimonium de eo falsum coram multitudine: Maledixit Naboth Deo et regi: quam ob rem eduxerunt eum extra civitatem, et lapidibus interfecerunt.
verses.english: Then they brought two worthless scoundrels, who sat opposite him and bore false testimony against him before the assembly, saying: 'Naboth cursed God and the king!' As a result, they led him outside the city and killed him with stones.

verses.latin: Miseruntque ad Jezabel, dicentes: Lapidatus est Naboth, et mortuus est.
verses.english: And they sent word to Jezebel, saying: 'Naboth has been stoned, and he is dead.'

verses.latin: Cum audisset autem Jezabel lapidatum Naboth, et mortuum, locuta est ad Achab, dicens: Surge, posside vineam Naboth Jezrahelitae, qui noluit tibi acquiescere, et vendere eam: non enim vivit Naboth, sed mortuus est.
verses.english: When Jezebel heard that Naboth had been stoned and was dead, she spoke to Ahab, saying: 'Get up and take possession of the vineyard of Naboth the Jezreelite, who refused to agree with you and sell it to you; for Naboth is no longer alive, but is dead.'

verses.latin: Quod cum audisset Achab, scilicet mortuum Naboth, surrexit, et descendit in vineam Naboth Jezrahelitae, ut possideret eam.
verses.english: When Ahab heard that Naboth was indeed dead, he got up and went down to the vineyard of Naboth the Jezreelite, to take possession of it.

verses.latin: Factum est autem verbum Domini ad Eliam Thesbitem, dicens:
verses.english: Then the word of the Lord came to Elijah the Tishbite, saying:

verses.latin: Surge, et descende in occursum Achab regis Israel, qui est in Samaria: ecce ipse descendit in vineam Naboth, ut possideat eam.
verses.english: 'Get up, and go down to meet Ahab, king of Israel, who is in Samaria. Look, he is now going down to Naboth's vineyard to take possession of it.

verses.latin: Et loqueris ad eum, dicens: Hæc dicit Dominus: Occidisti, quoque possedisti? Et post hæc addes: Hæc dicit Dominus: In loco in quo linxerunt canes sanguinem Naboth, ibi lambent et canes sanguinem tuum.
verses.english: And you shall speak to him, saying: 'Thus says the Lord: "Have you murdered, and also taken possession?" And after this you shall add: 'Thus says the Lord: "In the very place where dogs licked Naboth's blood, there also will dogs lick your own blood."

verses.latin: Et dixit Achab ad Eliam: Num invenisti me, inimice mi?
verses.english: And Ahab said to Elijah: 'Have you found me, O my enemy?'

verses.latin: Et ille respondit: Inveni, eo quod venundatus sis ut faceres malum in conspectu Domini.
verses.english: And he answered: 'I have found you, because you have sold yourself to do evil in the sight of the Lord.'

verses.latin: Ecce ego inducam super te malum, et demetam posteriora tua: et interficiam de Achab mingentem ad parietem, et clausum, et novissimum in Israel.
verses.english: 'Look, I will bring evil upon you and will cut off your descendants. I will destroy from Ahab everyone who urinates against a wall, both bond and free, and the very last in Israel.

verses.latin: Et faciam domum tuam sicut domum Jeroboam filii Nabat, et sicut domum Baasa filii Ahia: propter id quod irritasti, et peccare fecisti Israel.
verses.english: 'And I will make your house like the house of Jeroboam, son of Nebat, and like the house of Baasha, son of Ahijah, because you have provoked me to anger and have made Israel sin.'

verses.latin: Sed et de Jezabel locutus est Dominus, dicens: Canes comedent Jezabel in agro Jezrahel.
verses.english: Also, concerning Jezebel, the Lord has spoken, saying: 'Dogs shall devour Jezebel in the field of Jezreel.'

verses.latin: Si mortuus fuerit Achab in civitate, comedent eum canes: si autem mortuus fuerit in agro, comedent eum volucres caeli.
verses.english: If Ahab dies in the city, dogs will eat him; but if he dies in the open field, the birds of the sky will eat him.

verses.latin: Igitur non fuit alter talis sicut Achab, qui venditus est ut faceret malum in conspectu Domini: excitavit enim eum Jezabel uxor sua.
verses.english: Indeed, there was no one else like Ahab, who sold himself to do evil in the sight of the Lord; for his wife Jezebel incited him to do so.

verses.latin: Et abominabilis effectus est, ut sequeretur idola, et omnia quæ fecerant Amorrhæi, quos consummavit Dominus a facie filiorum Israel.
verses.english: He became utterly detestable by following idols and all the abominable practices that the Amorites had committed, whom the Lord had destroyed before the children of Israel.

verses.latin: Cum ergo audisset Achab sermones istos, scidit vestimenta sua, et operuit cilicio carnem suam: jejunavitque, et dormivit in sacco, et ambulavit demisso capite.
verses.english: When Ahab heard these words, he tore his garments and put on sackcloth over his flesh. He fasted, and slept in sackcloth, and walked with his head bowed down.

verses.latin: Et factum est verbum Domini ad Eliam Thesbitem, dicens: Nonne vidisti humiliatum Achab coram me? Idcirco quia humiliatus est mei causa, non inducam malum in diebus ejus: sed in diebus filii ejus inducam malum super domum ejus.
verses.english: Then the word of the Lord came to Elijah the Tishbite, saying: 'Have you not seen how Ahab has humbled himself before me? Therefore, because he has humbled himself for my sake, I will not bring the evil in his own days. Instead, in the days of his son, I will bring the evil upon his house.'

verses.latin: Et transierunt anni tres absque bello inter Syriam et Israel.
verses.english: And three years passed without any war between Syria and Israel.

verses.latin: In anno autem tertio descendit Josaphat rex Juda ad regem Israel.
verses.english: Then, in the third year, Jehoshaphat, the king of Judah, went down to visit the king of Israel.

verses.latin: Dixitque rex Israel ad servos suos: Num ignoratis quia Ramoth Galaad nostra est, et tacemus, ne auferatur de manibus nostris?
verses.english: The king of Israel then said to his servants, "Are you not aware that Ramoth-Gilead rightfully belongs to us, and yet we remain silent, allowing it to be taken from our hands?"

verses.latin: Dixitque ad Josaphat: Venire mecum in prælium ad Ramoth Galaad? Cui Josaphat respondit: Sicut ego, et tu; sicut populus meus, et populus tuus; sicut equi mei, et equi tui.
verses.english: He then asked Jehoshaphat, "Will you come with me to battle at Ramoth-Gilead?" Jehoshaphat replied, "I am with you, just as you are with me; my people are with your people; my horses are with your horses." This means they are fully allied.

verses.latin: Dixitque Josaphat ad regem Israel: Interroga, obsecro, hodie sermonem Domini.
verses.english: Jehoshaphat then said to the king of Israel, "Please, let us inquire today for a word from the Lord."

verses.latin: Congregavitque rex Israel prophetas, quadringentos viros, et dixit eis: Vadám ad Ramoth Galaad ad pugnandum, an quiescere debeo? Qui responderunt: Ascende, et dabit Dominus in manu regis.
verses.english: So the king of Israel gathered four hundred prophets and asked them, "Should I go to Ramoth-Gilead to fight, or should I hold back?" They all responded, "Go up, and the Lord will deliver it into the king's hand."

verses.latin: Dixitque Josaphat: Nonne est hic propheta Domini, ut interrogemus per eum?
verses.english: Jehoshaphat then asked, "Is there not also a prophet of the Lord here, so that we may inquire through him?"

verses.latin: Et ait rex Israel ad Josaphat: Est vir unus per quem possumus interrrogare Dominum, sed ego odi eum, quia non prophetat mihi bonum, sed malum, Micheas filius Jemla. Cui Josaphat respondit: Ne loquaris, rex, sermone isto.
verses.english: The king of Israel said to Jehoshaphat, "There is one man through whom we can inquire of the Lord, but I hate him, because he never prophesies anything good for me, only evil. His name is Micaiah, the son of Imlah." Jehoshaphat replied, "Do not speak such words, my king."

verses.latin: Vocavit ergo rex Israel eunuchum unum, et dixit ei: Festina adducere Michæam filium Jemla.
verses.english: So the king of Israel called one of his eunuchs and told him, "Go quickly and bring Micaiah, the son of Imlah."

verses.latin: Rex autem Israel et Josaphat rex Juda sedebant, uterque in solio suo, vestiti cultu regio, in area juxta ostium portæ Samariæ: et omnes prophetæ vaticinabantur coram eis.
verses.english: Now, the king of Israel and Jehoshaphat, the king of Judah, were both sitting on their thrones, dressed in their royal robes, in the threshing floor area near the entrance of the gate of Samaria. All the other prophets were delivering their prophecies before them.

verses.latin: Fecitque sibi Sedecias filius Chanaana cornua ferrea, et ait: Hæc dicit Dominus: His ventilabis Syriam, donec deleas eam.
verses.english: And Zedekiah, the son of Chenaanah, had made for himself horns of iron and declared, "Thus says the Lord: 'With these horns, you will gore and scatter Syria until you have utterly destroyed them.'"

verses.latin: Et omnes prophetæ similiter prophetabant, dicentes: Ascende in Ramoth Galaad, et prosperaberis, et dabit Dominus in manu regis.
verses.english: All the other prophets were also prophesying similarly, saying, "Go up to Ramoth-Gilead, and you will succeed, for the Lord will deliver it into the king's hand."

verses.latin: Nuntius igitur, qui ierat ad vocandum Michæam, locutus est ei, dicens: Ecce sermones prophetarum quasi ore uno bona regi annuntiant: sit ergo sermo tuus similis eorum, et loquere bona.
verses.english: So the messenger who had gone to summon Micaiah spoke to him, saying, "Look, the words of all the prophets are unanimously declaring good things for the king. Therefore, let your words be like theirs, and speak good tidings."

verses.latin: Cui respondit Michæas: Vivit Dominus, quia quodcumque mihi dixerit Dominus, hoc loquar.
verses.english: Micaiah replied to him, "As the Lord lives, whatever the Lord tells me to say, that is what I will speak." This shows his unwavering commitment to God's true message.

verses.latin: Venit itaque ad regem. Et ait illi rex: Michæa, ire debemus in Ramoth Galaad ad præliandum, an debemus quiescere? Qui respondit ei: Ascende, et prosperaberis, et dabit Dominus in manu regis.
verses.english: So he came to the king. The king asked him, "Micaiah, should we go to Ramoth-Gilead to fight, or should we hold back?" Micaiah replied to him, "Go up, and you will succeed; the Lord will deliver it into the king's hand."

verses.latin: Dixitque rex ad eum: Iterum atque iterum adjuro te, ut non loquaris mihi nisi quod verum est in nomine Domini.
verses.english: The king then said to him, "I adjure you, again and again, that you speak nothing to me but what is true, in the name of the Lord." The king knew Micaiah was being sarcastic.

verses.latin: Qui ait: Vidi omnem Israël dispersum in montibus, quasi oves non habentes pastorem. Et ait Dominus: Non habent isti domini mei: revertatur unusquisque in domum suam cum pace.
verses.english: Micaiah then said: "I saw all of Israel scattered on the mountains like sheep without a shepherd. And the Lord said: 'These people have no master now. Let each one return to his home in peace.'" This was a prophecy of the king's death.

verses.latin: Dixit ergo rex Israël ad Josaphat: Numquid non dixi tibi, quia non prophetat mihi bonum, sed semper malum?
verses.english: So the king of Israel said to Jehoshaphat, "Did I not tell you that he never prophesies anything good for me, but always evil?"

verses.latin: Et ille ait: Propter hoc audi sermonem Domini: Vidi Dominum sedentem super solium suum, et omnem exercitum cæli assistentem ei a dextris et a sinistris.
verses.english: Micaiah then said, "Therefore, hear the word of the Lord: I saw the Lord sitting on His throne, with all the host of heaven standing by Him on His right and on His left." This describes a heavenly council.

verses.latin: Et dixit Dominus: Quis decipiet Achab regem Israël, ut ascendat, et cadat in Ramoth Galaad? Et dixit unus verbum hoc, et alius illud.
verses.english: And the Lord said, "Who will entice Ahab, the king of Israel, to go up and fall at Ramoth-Gilead?" And one spirit said one thing, and another spirit said another.

verses.latin: Egressusque est spiritus, et stetit coram Domino, et ait: Ego decipiam illum. Cui locutus est Dominus: In quo?
verses.english: Then a certain spirit came forward and stood before the Lord and said, "I will entice him." The Lord asked him, "How will you do it?"

verses.latin: Et ille ait: Egrediar, et ero spiritus mendax in ore omnium prophetarum ejus. Et dixit Dominus: Decipies, et prævalebis: egredere, et fac ita.
verses.english: And the spirit said, "I will go out and become a lying spirit in the mouths of all his prophets." And the Lord said, "You will entice him, and you will succeed. Go out and do as you have said." This means God allowed the deception.

verses.latin: Nunc ergo ecce dedit Dominus spiritum mendacii in ore omnium prophetarum tuorum, et Dominus locutus est adversum te malum.
verses.english: "So now, behold, the Lord has put a lying spirit in the mouths of all these prophets of yours, and the Lord has decreed evil concerning you."

verses.latin: Accedens autem Sedecias filius Chanaana, percussit Michæam in maxillam, et ait: Per quam viam abivit a me spiritus Domini, ut loqueretur tibi?
verses.english: Then Zedekiah, the son of Chenaanah, approached and struck Micaiah on the cheek, saying, "Which way did the Spirit of the Lord pass from me to speak to you instead?"

verses.latin: Et dixit Michæas: Tu videbis in die illo, quando ingredieris cubiculum de cubiculo ut abscondaris.
verses.english: Micaiah replied, "You will see on that day when you go into an inner room from chamber to chamber to hide yourself."

verses.latin: Et ait rex Israël: Tollite Michæam, et ducite eum ad Amon principem civitatis, et ad Joas filium Amelech.
verses.english: The king of Israel then said, "Take Micaiah and lead him to Amon, the governor of the city, and to Joash, the son of Amelech."

verses.latin: Et dicetis: Hæc dicit rex: Mittite hunc in carcerem, et sustentate eum pane afflictionis, et aqua angustiæ, donec revertar in pace.
verses.english: "And tell them: 'Thus says the king: Put this man in prison and feed him with the bread of affliction and the water of distress until I return in peace.'"

verses.latin: Et ait Michæas: Si reversus fueris in pace, non est locutus Dominus in me. Et dixit: Audite populi omnes.
verses.english: Micaiah said, "If you ever return in peace, then the Lord has not spoken through me." And he added, "Hear this, all you peoples!"

verses.latin: Igitur rex Israël et Josaphat rex Juda, ascenderunt in Ramoth Galaad.
verses.english: So the king of Israel and Jehoshaphat, the king of Judah, went up to Ramoth-Gilead.

verses.latin: Dixitque rex Israël ad Josaphat: Mutabo habitum meum, et ingrediar pugnam: tu autem induere vestibus tuis. Mutavit ergo rex Israël habitum suum, et ingressus est pugnam.
verses.english: The king of Israel said to Jehoshaphat, "I will disguise myself and go into battle, but you wear your royal robes." So the king of Israel disguised himself and went into battle.

verses.latin: Rex autem Syriæ præceperat principibus curruum triginta duobus, dicens: Non pugnabitis contra minorem et majorem, nisi contra regem Israël solum.
verses.english: Now the king of Syria had commanded his thirty-two chariot commanders, saying, "Do not fight with anyone, neither small nor great, except with the king of Israel alone."

verses.latin: Cum ergo vidissent principes curruum Josaphat, susceperunt eum, dicentes: Rex Israël iste est. Et irruerunt super eum.
verses.english: So when the chariot commanders saw Jehoshaphat, they assumed he was the king of Israel and turned to attack him.

verses.latin: Clamavitque Josaphat, et avertit eum Dominus, et inclinavit eos a Josaphat.
verses.english: But Jehoshaphat cried out, and the Lord turned them away from him, causing them to turn from pursuing Jehoshaphat.

verses.latin: Vir autem quidam tetendit arcum, et sagittas dirigens, casu percussit regem Israël inter pulmonem et stomachum. At ille dixit curru suo: Converte manum tuam, et educ me de acie, quia vulneratus sum graviter.
verses.english: However, a certain man drew his bow with careful aim and by chance struck the king of Israel between his lung and stomach. The king then said to his chariot driver, "Turn around and take me out of the battle, for I am severely wounded."

verses.latin: Instabat ergo prælium in die illo, et rex Israël stabat in curru suo contra Syros, et mortuus est vespere: et fluebat sanguis plaga in sinum currus.
verses.english: The battle raged on throughout that day, and the king of Israel remained standing in his chariot facing the Syrians. He died that evening, as the blood from his wound flowed into the floor of the chariot.

verses.latin: Et præco clamavit in universo exercitu ante solis occasum, dicens: Unusquisque ad civitatem suam, et unusquisque ad terram suam.
verses.english: And a herald cried out throughout the entire army before sunset, saying, "Every man to his own city, and every man to his own land!"

verses.latin: Et mortuus est rex, et perlatus est Samariam: et sepelierunt regem in Samaria.
verses.english: So the king died and was brought to Samaria, and they buried the king in Samaria.

verses.latin: Et laverunt currum in piscinam Samariæ: et linguerunt canes sanguinem ejus, et scorta laverunt se juxta sermonem Domini, quem locutus fuerat.
verses.english: And they washed the chariot in the pool of Samaria, where the dogs licked up his blood, and the harlots washed themselves, just as the Lord had prophesied.

verses.latin: Reliqua autem sermonum Achab, et universa quæ fecit, et domus eburnea, quam ædificavit, et omnia civitates quas construxit, nonne hæc scripta sunt in libro sermonum dierum regum Israël?
verses.english: As for the rest of the acts of Ahab, and everything he did, and the ivory house that he built, and all the cities that he constructed—are these not written in the book of the chronicles of the kings of Israel?

verses.latin: Dormivit igitur Achab cum patribus suis: et regnavit Ochozias filius ejus pro eo.
verses.english: So Ahab rested with his ancestors, and his son Ahaziah reigned in his place.

verses.latin: Sedebant autem tres anni absque bello inter Syriam et Israel.
verses.english: Now, there were three years of peace between Syria and Israel.

verses.latin: In anno autem tertio descendit Josaphat rex Juda ad regem Israel.
verses.english: But in the third year, Jehoshaphat, the king of Judah, went down to visit the king of Israel.

verses.latin: Dixitque rex Israel ad servos suos: Num ignoratis quia Ramoth Galaad nostra est, et tacemus, ne accipiamus eam de manu regis Syriae?
verses.english: The king of Israel said to his servants, "Don't you realize that Ramoth in Gilead belongs to us? Why do we remain silent and not take it back from the king of Syria?"

verses.latin: Dixitque ad Josaphat: Venire mecum ad praelium in Ramoth Galaad? Cui respondit Josaphat: Sicut ego, et tu; sicut populus tuus, et populus meus; et equites tui, equites mei.
verses.english: Then he said to Jehoshaphat, "Will you come with me to battle in Ramoth-Gilead?" Jehoshaphat replied, "I am as you are, and my people are as your people, and my horsemen are as your horsemen. We are allies."

verses.latin: Dixitque Josaphat ad regem Israel: Interroga, obsecro, hodie sermonem Domini.
verses.english: Jehoshaphat then said to the king of Israel, "Please, let us inquire of the Lord today to hear His word."

verses.latin: Congregavit igitur rex Israel prophetas, quadringentos viros, et dixit eis: Vadame ad Ramoth Galaad ad bellandum, an quiescere debeo? Qui responderunt: Ascende, et dabis eam in manu regis.
verses.english: So the king of Israel gathered the prophets—about four hundred men—and asked them, "Should I go to Ramoth-Gilead to wage war, or should I hold back?" They all answered, "Go up, and God will give it into the king's hand."

verses.latin: Dixitque Josaphat: Numquid non est hic propheta Domini, ut interrogemus per eum?
verses.english: Jehoshaphat asked, "Is there no other prophet of the Lord here, so that we may inquire through him?"

verses.latin: Et ait rex Israel ad Josaphat: Est vir unus, per quem possumus interrogare Dominum, sed ego odi eum, quia non prophetat mihi bonum, sed malum: Michaeas filius Jemla. Cui Josaphat respondit: Ne loquaris, rex, sermone isto.
verses.english: The king of Israel said to Jehoshaphat, "There is one man through whom we could inquire of the Lord, but I hate him, because he never prophesies anything good for me, only evil. That man is Micaiah, the son of Imlah." Jehoshaphat responded, "The king should not speak like that."

verses.latin: Vocavit ergo rex Israel eunuchum unum, et dixit ei: Festina adducere Michaeam filium Jemla.
verses.english: So the king of Israel called one of his officials and ordered him, "Quickly, bring Micaiah, the son of Imlah."

verses.latin: Rex autem Israel, et Josaphat rex Juda, sedebant, uterque in solio suo, vestiti cultu regio in area juxta introitum portae Samariae: et omnes prophetae vaticinabantur coram eis.
verses.english: The king of Israel and Jehoshaphat, the king of Judah, were sitting, each on his throne, dressed in their royal robes, in the open space at the entrance to the gate of Samaria. All the other prophets were prophesying before them.

verses.latin: Fecit quoque sibi Sedecias filius Chanaana cornua ferrea, et ait: Haec dicit Dominus: His ventilabis Syriam donec deleas eam.
verses.english: Then Zedekiah, the son of Chenaanah, made himself iron horns and declared, "Thus says the Lord: 'With these, you will gore the Syrians until you utterly destroy them.'"

verses.latin: Et omnes prophetae similiter prophetabant, dicentes: Ascende in Ramoth Galaad, et prospere omnia habebunt, et dabit Dominus in manu regis.
verses.english: All the other prophets prophesied similarly, saying, "Go up to Ramoth-Gilead! You will succeed in everything, and the Lord will deliver it into the king's hand."

verses.latin: Nuntius igitur qui ierat ad vocandum Michaeam, locutus est ad eum, dicens: Ecce sermones prophetarum quasi ex uno ore bona regi annuntiant: esto ergo sermo tuus similis eorum, et loquere bona.
verses.english: The messenger who had gone to summon Micaiah spoke to him, saying, "Look, the words of the prophets are uniformly favorable for the king. So let your words be like theirs, and speak favorably."

verses.latin: Cui respondit Michaeas: Vivit Dominus, quia quodcumque mihi dixerit Dominus, hoc loquar.
verses.english: Micaiah replied, "As the Lord lives, I will speak only what the Lord tells me to say."

verses.latin: Venit ergo ad regem: et ait rex ad eum: Michaea, ire debemus in Ramoth Galaad ad bellandum, an quiescere? Qui respondit ei: Ascende, et prospere omnia habebunt, et tradet Dominus in manus regis.
verses.english: When he came to the king, the king asked him, "Micaiah, should we go to Ramoth-Gilead to wage war, or should we hold back?" Micaiah answered him, "Go up, and you will succeed in everything, and the Lord will deliver it into the king's hand." This was said with sarcasm.

verses.latin: Dixitque rex: Iterum atque iterum adjuro te, ut non loquaris mihi nisi quod verum est in nomine Domini.
verses.english: The king said, "How many times must I make you swear by God that you will tell me nothing but the truth in the name of the Lord?"

verses.latin: Qui ait: Vidi omnem Israel dispersum in montibus, quasi oves non habentes pastorem: et ait Dominus: Non est his princeps; revertatur unusquisque in domum suam cum pace.
verses.english: Micaiah then said, "I saw all Israel scattered on the mountains like sheep without a shepherd. And the Lord said, 'These people have no leader. Let each one return to his house in peace.'"

verses.latin: Dixit ergo rex Israel ad Josaphat: Numquid non dixi tibi, quod non prophetet mihi bonum, sed semper malum?
verses.english: The king of Israel then said to Jehoshaphat, "Didn't I tell you that he never prophesies anything good for me, but always evil?"

verses.latin: At ille ait: Propter hoc audi sermonem Domini: Vidi Dominum sedentem super solium suum, et omnem exercitum caeli assistentem ei a dextris et a sinistris.
verses.english: Micaiah continued, "Therefore, hear the word of the Lord. I saw the Lord sitting on His throne, and all the host of heaven standing by Him on His right and on His left."

verses.latin: Et dixit Dominus: Quis decipiet Achab regem Israel, ut ascendat, et cadat in Ramoth Galaad? Et dixit unus verbum hoc, et alius ait alio modo.
verses.english: And the Lord said, "Who will entice Ahab, the king of Israel, so that he goes up and falls in Ramoth-Gilead?" One spirit suggested one thing, and another suggested a different method.

verses.latin: Egressusque est spiritus, et stetit coram Domino, et ait: Ego decipiam eum. Cui dixit Dominus: In quo?
verses.english: Then a spirit came forward and stood before the Lord, saying, "I will entice him." The Lord asked him, "How will you do it?"

verses.latin: Et ille ait: Exibo, et ero spiritus mendax in ore omnium prophetarum ejus. Et dixit Dominus: Decipies, et praevalebis: egredere, et fac ita.
verses.english: The spirit replied, "I will go out and become a lying spirit in the mouths of all his prophets." The Lord said, "You will entice him, and you will succeed. Go out and do so."

verses.latin: Nunc igitur ecce dedit Dominus spiritum mendacii in ore omnium prophetarum tuorum qui hic sunt, et Dominus locutus est contra te malum.
verses.english: Now therefore, behold, the Lord has put a lying spirit in the mouths of all these prophets of yours who are here. And the Lord has spoken disaster against you.

verses.latin: Accedens autem Sedecias filius Chanaana, percussit Michaeam in maxillam, et dixit: Per quam viam abiit spiritus Domini a me, ut loqueretur tibi?
verses.english: Then Zedekiah, the son of Chenaanah, came up and struck Micaiah on the cheek, saying, "Which way did the Spirit of the Lord leave me to speak to you?"

verses.latin: Et ait Michaeas: Tu videbis in die illo, quando ingredieris cubiculum de cubiculo ut abscondaris.
verses.english: Micaiah answered, "You will see on that day when you go into an inner room, hiding from everyone, trying to escape."

verses.latin: Et ait rex Israel: Tollite Michaeam, et ducite eum ad Amon principem civitatis, et ad Joas filium Amelech,
verses.english: The king of Israel then ordered, "Take Micaiah and lead him back to Amon, the governor of the city, and to Joash, the king's son."

verses.latin: et dicetis: Haec dicit rex: Mittite hunc in carcerem, et sustentate eum pane afflictionis, et aqua angustiae, donec revertar in pace.
verses.english: And tell them, "The king says: 'Put this man in prison and feed him only meager rations of bread and water until I return victorious and in peace.'"

verses.latin: Dixitque Michaeas: Si reversus fueris in pace, non est locutus Dominus in me. Et ait: Audite, populi omnes.
verses.english: Micaiah declared, "If you ever return in peace, then the Lord has not spoken through me." And he added, "Listen, all you people!"

verses.latin: Igitur rex Israel, et Josaphat rex Juda, ascenderunt in Ramoth Galaad.
verses.english: So the king of Israel and Jehoshaphat, the king of Judah, went up to Ramoth-Gilead.

verses.latin: Dixitque rex Israel ad Josaphat: Mutable habitu meo, et ingrediar praelium, tu autem induere vestimentis tuis. Mutavit ergo rex Israel habitum suum, et intravit praelium.
verses.english: The king of Israel said to Jehoshaphat, "I will disguise myself before I enter the battle, but you wear your royal robes." So the king of Israel disguised himself and went into battle.

verses.latin: Rex autem Syriae praeceperat principibus curruum triginta duobus, dicens: Non pugnabitis contra minorem, et contra majorem, nisi contra regem Israel solum.
verses.english: The king of Syria had commanded his thirty-two chariot commanders, saying, "Do not fight with anyone, small or great, except for the king of Israel alone."

verses.latin: Cum ergo vidissent principes curruum Josaphat, suspicati sunt quod ipse esset rex Israel, et concitati impetum fecerunt in eum: et exclamavit Josaphat.
verses.english: So when the chariot commanders saw Jehoshaphat, they assumed he was the king of Israel, and they turned to attack him. But Jehoshaphat cried out.

verses.latin: Intellexeruntque principes curruum quod non esset rex Israel, et declinaverunt ab eo.
verses.english: The chariot commanders realized that he was not the king of Israel, so they turned away from pursuing him.

verses.latin: Vir autem quidam tetendit arcum in incertum, et interfecit regem Israel inter pulmonem et stomachum. At ille dixit aurigae suo: Converte manum tuam, et ejice me de acie, quia vulneratus sum valde.
verses.english: But a certain man drew his bow at random, without aiming, and struck the king of Israel between his lung and his stomach. The king said to his chariot driver, "Turn your hand, and take me out of the battle line, because I am severely wounded."

verses.latin: Et consertum est proelium in die illo: stetit autem rex Israel in curru suo contra Syros, et mortuus est vespere, et effusus est sanguis de vulnere in medium currus.
verses.english: The battle intensified throughout that day. The king of Israel remained propped up in his chariot facing the Syrians. He died in the evening, and the blood from his wound flowed into the bottom of the chariot.

verses.latin: Et clamavit praeco per universum exercitum ante solis occasum, dicens: Unusquisque revertatur in civitatem, et unusquisque in terram suam.
verses.english: At sunset, a proclamation was made throughout the entire army, saying, "Every man return to his city, and every man to his own land!"

verses.latin: Et mortuus est rex, et perlatus est Samariam: sepelieruntque regem in Samaria.
verses.english: So the king died, and he was brought to Samaria. They buried the king in Samaria.

verses.latin: Et laverunt currum in piscinam Samariae, et linguerunt canes sanguinem ejus, et scorta laverunt se juxta sermonem Domini quem locutus fuerat.
verses.english: When they washed the chariot in the pool of Samaria, the dogs licked up his blood, and the harlots bathed in that very water—just as the Lord had prophesied would happen.

verses.latin: Reliqua autem sermonum Achab, et universa quae fecit, et domus eburnea quam aedificavit, et cuncta opera quae operatus est, nonne haec scripta sunt in libro sermonum dierum regum Israel?
verses.english: Now, the rest of the acts of Ahab, and all that he did, and the ivory palace he built, and all the works he accomplished, are they not written in the Book of the Chronicles of the Kings of Israel?

verses.latin: Dormivit igitur Achab cum patribus suis: et regnavit Ochozias filius ejus pro eo.
verses.english: So Ahab slept with his fathers—meaning he died—and Ahaziah, his son, reigned in his place.

verses.latin: Et transierunt tres anni absque bello inter Syriam et Israel.
verses.english: And three years passed without any war between the kingdom of Syria and the kingdom of Israel.

verses.latin: Anno autem tertio descendit Josaphat rex Juda ad regem Israël.
verses.english: Then, in the third year, Josaphat, who was the king of Judah, went down to visit the king of Israel.

verses.latin: Dixitque rex Israël ad servos suos: Num ignoratis quia Ramoth Galaad nostra est, et tacemus, ne auferatur de manibus nostris?
verses.english: Now, the king of Israel spoke to his servants, saying: "Do you not know that the city of Ramoth Galaad belongs to us? Yet we remain silent, doing nothing to prevent it from being taken from our hands!"

verses.latin: Dixitque ad Josaphat: Venire mecum in prælium contra Ramoth Galaad?
verses.english: And the king of Israel then asked Josaphat: "Will you come with me to fight in battle against Ramoth Galaad?"

verses.latin: Et respondit Josaphat regi Israël: Sicut ego, sic et tu: sicut populus meus, sic et populus tuus, et equi mei, equi tui.
verses.english: Josaphat replied to the king of Israel: "I am with you as if I were you. My people are with you as if they were your people, and my horses are with you as if they were your horses—we are united as one." This was Josaphat's promise of military alliance.

verses.latin: Dixitque Josaphat ad regem Israël: Interroga, obsecro, hodie sermonem Domini.
verses.english: Josaphat then said to the king of Israel: "Please, I beg you, let us inquire today for a word from the Lord."

verses.latin: Congregavit igitur rex Israël prophetas quadringentos, et dixit eis: Vadame ad Ramoth Galaad ad pugnandum, an cessare debeo? Qui responderunt: Ascende, et dabis eam Dominus in manu regis.
verses.english: So the king of Israel gathered about four hundred of his own prophets and asked them: "Should I go to Ramoth Galaad to fight, or should I hold back?" They all answered him: "Go up into battle! The Lord will give the city into the king's hand."

verses.latin: Dixitque Josaphat: Nonne est hic propheta Domini adhuc, ut interrogemus per eum?
verses.english: But Josaphat asked: "Is there no other true prophet of the Lord here through whom we can inquire further?"

verses.latin: Et ait rex Israël ad Josaphat: Est vir unus, per quem possumus interrogare Dominum, sed ego odi eum: quia non prophetat mihi bonum, sed malum, Michæas filius Jemla. Cui Josaphat: Ne loquaris, inquit, rex sic.
verses.english: The king of Israel replied to Josaphat: "There is one more man by whom we could inquire of the Lord, but I hate him. He never prophesies anything good for me, only evil. His name is Michæas, the son of Jemla." Josaphat responded, saying: "The king should not speak like that!"

verses.latin: Vocavit ergo rex Israël eunuchum unum, et dixit ei: Festina adducere Michæam filium Jemla.
verses.english: So the king of Israel called one of his eunuchs and ordered him: "Hurry and bring Michæas, the son of Jemla, here!"

verses.latin: Rex autem Israël et Josaphat rex Juda sedebant, uterque in solio suo, vestiti cultu regio in area juxta ostium portæ Samariæ: et omnes prophetæ vaticinabantur coram eis.
verses.english: Now the king of Israel and Josaphat, the king of Judah, were sitting, each on his own throne. They were dressed in their royal robes in the open area near the gate of Samaria, and all the prophets were prophesying before them, delivering their messages.

verses.latin: Fecerat igitur sibi Sedecias filius Chanana cornua ferrea, et dixerat: Hæc dicit Dominus: His ventilabis Syriam, donec deleas eam.
verses.english: Indeed, Sedecias, the son of Chanana, had made himself horns of iron and declared: "This is what the Lord says: With these horns you will push Syria until you completely destroy them."

verses.latin: Omnesque prophetæ similiter prophetabant, dicentes: Ascende in Ramoth Galaad, et prosperaberis: dabitque Dominus in manu regis.
verses.english: And all the other prophets prophesied similarly, saying: "Go up to Ramoth Galaad, and you will be successful! The Lord will give it into the king's hand."

verses.latin: Nuntius autem, qui ierat ad vocandum Michæam, locutus est ad eum, dicens: Ecce, sermones prophetarum quasi ore uno bona regi annuntiant: sit ergo sermo tuus similis eorum, et loquere bona.
verses.english: But the messenger who had gone to summon Michæas spoke to him, saying: "Look, the words of the prophets are all proclaiming good things to the king with one voice. So let your words be like theirs, and speak favorably."

verses.latin: Cui Michæas: Vivit Dominus, quia quodcumque mihi dixerit Dominus, hoc loquar.
verses.english: Michæas responded to the messenger: "As the Lord lives, I will speak only whatever the Lord tells me."

verses.latin: Venit ergo ad regem: et ait illi rex: Michæa, ire debemus in Ramoth Galaad ad bellandum, an cessare?
verses.english: So when he came before the king, the king asked him: "Michæas, should we go to Ramoth Galaad to wage war, or should we hold back?"

verses.latin: Cui ille respondit: Ascende, et prosperaberis, et dabit illam Dominus in manu regis.
verses.english: Michæas answered him, speaking sarcastically: "Go up, and you will be successful! The Lord will give it into the king's hand!"

verses.latin: Et ait rex: Iterum atque iterum adjuro te, ut non loquaris mihi nisi quod verum est in nomine Domini.
verses.english: The king then said: "How many times must I warn you and adjure you under oath, that you speak to me nothing but the truth in the name of the Lord?"

verses.latin: Et ille ait: Vidi omnem Israël dispersum in montibus, quasi oves non habentes pastorem. Et ait Dominus: Non habent isti dominum: revertatur unusquisque in domum suam in pace.
verses.english: Michæas replied: "I saw all of Israel scattered on the mountains, like sheep without a shepherd. And the Lord said: 'These people have no master. Let each one return to his own home in peace.'" This was a prophecy of the king's death.

verses.latin: Dixit igitur rex Israël ad Josaphat: Numquid non dixi tibi, quia non prophetat mihi bonum, sed semper malum?
verses.english: Then the king of Israel said to Josaphat: "Did I not tell you that he never prophesies good for me, but always evil?"

verses.latin: At ille addens, ait: Propterea audi sermonem Domini: Vidi Dominum sedentem super solium suum, et omnem exercitum cæli assistentem ei a dextris et a sinistris.
verses.english: But Michæas continued, saying: "Therefore, hear the word of the Lord. I saw the Lord sitting upon His throne, and all the host of heaven standing by Him on His right hand and on His left."

verses.latin: Et dixit Dominus: Quis decipiet Achab regem Israël, ut ascendat, et cadat in Ramoth Galaad? Et dixit unus verba hæc, et alius alia.
verses.english: And the Lord asked: 'Who will deceive Achab, the king of Israel, so that he will go up to Ramoth Galaad and fall there?' And one spirit spoke these words, and another spoke other words.

verses.latin: Egressusque est spiritus, et stetit coram Domino, et ait: Ego decipiam illum. Cui locutus est Dominus: In quo?
verses.english: Then a certain spirit came forth and stood before the Lord and said: 'I will deceive him.' The Lord asked him: 'How will you do it?'

verses.latin: Et ille ait: Egrediar, et ero spiritus mendax in ore omnium prophetarum ejus. Dixitque Dominus: Decipies, et prævalebis: egredere, et fac ita.
verses.english: And the spirit said: 'I will go out and be a lying spirit in the mouth of all his prophets.' The Lord then said: 'You will deceive him, and you will prevail. Go out and do it in this manner.'

verses.latin: Nunc igitur ecce dedit Dominus spiritum mendacii in ore omnium prophetarum tuorum, et Dominus locutus est de te mala.
verses.english: Now therefore, behold, the Lord has put a lying spirit in the mouth of all these prophets of yours, and the Lord has spoken evil concerning you.

verses.latin: Accessit autem Sedecias filius Chanana, et percussit Michæam in maxillam, et dixit: Per quam viam abiit spiritus Domini a me, ut loqueretur tibi?
verses.english: Then Sedecias, the son of Chanana, approached and struck Michæas on the cheek, saying: "By what way did the Spirit of the Lord depart from me to speak to you instead?"

verses.latin: Et Michæas: Ecce, inquit, videbis in die illa, quando ingredieris cubiculum de cubiculo, ut abscondaris.
verses.english: Michæas responded: "Behold, you will see on that day, when you go from chamber to inner chamber to hide yourself—fleeing from the battle."

verses.latin: Et ait rex Israël: Tollite Michæam, et ducite eum ad Amon principem civitatis, et ad Joas filium Amelech,
verses.english: And the king of Israel commanded: "Take Michæas and lead him to Amon, the governor of the city, and to Joas, the son of Amelech."

verses.latin: et dicite: Hæc dicit rex: Mittite hunc in carcerem, et date ei panem afflictionis, et aquam angustiæ, donec revertar in pace.
verses.english: And say: 'This is what the king says: Put this man in prison and feed him with the bread of affliction and the water of distress, until I return victorious and in peace.'"

verses.latin: Dixitque Michæas: Si reversus fueris in pace, non est locutus Dominus in me. Et ait: Audite, populi omnes.
verses.english: Michæas then declared: "If you indeed return victorious and in peace, then the Lord has not spoken through me." And he added: "Hear this, all you peoples!"

verses.latin: Igitur rex Israël et Josaphat rex Juda ascenderunt in Ramoth Galaad.
verses.english: So the king of Israel and Josaphat, the king of Judah, went up to Ramoth Galaad.

verses.latin: Dixitque rex Israël ad Josaphat: Converte te, et induere vestimentis tuis. Ego autem induar alio habitu, et sic veniam ad prælium. Mutavit ergo rex Israël habitum suum, et venit ad bellum.
verses.english: And the king of Israel said to Josaphat: "You, disguise yourself by putting on other clothes. But I will disguise myself in a different manner and then go into battle." So the king of Israel changed his royal attire and went into the war.

verses.latin: Rex autem Syriæ præceperat principibus curruum triginta duobus, dicens: Non pugnabitis contra minorem aut majorem, nisi contra regem Israël solum.
verses.english: Now the king of Syria had commanded his thirty-two chariot captains, saying: "Do not fight against anyone, neither small nor great, except against the king of Israel alone."

verses.latin: Cum ergo vidissent principes curruum Josaphat, suspexerunt et dixerunt: Rex Israël iste est. Irrueruntque super eum pugnantes: et exclamavit Josaphat.
verses.english: When the chariot captains saw Josaphat, they assumed and said: "This must be the king of Israel!" So they turned to attack him in battle, and Josaphat cried out for help.

verses.latin: Et intellexerunt principes curruum quod non esset rex Israël: recesseruntque ab eo.
verses.english: And the chariot captains realized that it was not the king of Israel, so they turned away from pursuing him.

verses.latin: Vir autem quidam tetendit arcum, et in incertum sagittam dirigens, interfecit regem Israël inter juncturam et thoracem. At ille ait curru suo: Converte manum tuam, et ejice me de acie, quia vulneratus sum.
verses.english: However, a certain man drew his bow and, shooting an arrow randomly, struck the king of Israel between the shoulder armor and the breastplate. The king then cried out to his chariot driver: "Turn around and take me out of this battle, because I have been seriously wounded!"

verses.latin: Et instabat prælium in die illa: porro rex Israël stabat in curru suo contra Syros, et mortuus est vespere, et effusus est sanguis de vulnere in medium currus.
verses.english: And the battle raged fiercely throughout that day. The king of Israel remained standing in his chariot, facing the Syrians, until he died at evening. The blood from his wound flowed out onto the floor of the chariot.

verses.latin: Et translatione facta S.maria sepelierunt regem in Samaria.
verses.english: After his body was brought to Samaria, they buried the king in Samaria.

verses.latin: Et lotum est currus in piscina Samariæ: et linguerunt canes sanguinem ejus, et scorta laverunt, juxta verbum Domini, quod locutus fuerat.
verses.english: His chariot was then washed in the pool of Samaria. The dogs licked up his blood, and the harlots washed themselves there. This happened exactly according to the word of the Lord, which He had spoken through His prophet Michæas.

verses.latin: Reliqua autem sermonum Achab, et universa quæ fecit, et domus eburnea quam ædificavit, et omnia oppida quæ construxit, nonne hæc scripta sunt in libro sermonum dierum regum Israël?
verses.english: As for the rest of the acts of Achab, and all that he did, including the ivory house he built and all the cities he constructed, are these not written in the Book of the Chronicles of the Kings of Israel?
